QUESTION [by Agri Team]: After irrigation, when should the next watering be avoided?
Final Answer:
The critical stages of irrigation in wheat are those where water stress can cause maximum yield loss.
The most important stage is the Crown Root Initiation (CRI) stage at 20–25 days after sowing, which is essential for root development and tillering. The second critical stage is tillering (40–45 DAS), when side shoots develop and determine the number of productive tillers.
The jointing stage (stem elongation) also requires adequate moisture for healthy crop growth.
Irrigation at the flowering stage ensures proper pollination and grain set, while irrigation during the grain-filling or milk/dough stage supports kernel development and prevents shriveled grains.
However, irrigation should be avoided immediately after sowing to prevent seed rotting, as well as just before crop maturity, since excess moisture at this stage can reduce grain quality and delay harvesting. During cloudy days, irrigation must also be avoided to prevent lodging of the crop. The next irrigation in wheat should not be applied immediately after the previous one but only after the soil moisture has been adequately utilized by the crop.
On average, wheat requires 4–6 irrigations depending on soil type and climate, but CRI, tillering, flowering, and grain filling are considered the most critical for achieving high yield.
Over-irrigation or excessively frequent watering can lead to waterlogging, poor root growth, and an increased risk of diseases. Specifically, irrigation must be avoided immediately after sowing to prevent seed rotting and just before crop maturity, as excess moisture at that time reduces grain quality and delays harvesting.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Alternaria Leaf Spot in Cotton?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Gulli danda (Phalaris minor) in Wheat crop?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bacterial Leaf Spot in Pomegranate?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bollworm in Cotton?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Fruit Borer in Okra?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Damping-off disease in Paddy seedlings in the nursery?

Due to this, seedlings are rotted at the base, fall over, and wet, brown patches are seen in the nursery. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control downy mildew disease in bottle gourd?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Downy Mildew in Cauliflower crop?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Downy Mildew in Muskmelon?

Avoid planting muskmelons or other cucurbits (cucumber, bottle gourd) in the same field year after year and rotate with legumes or vegetables. Grow muskmelon in well-drained soil with good sunlight exposure, and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness. Spray protective fungicides, i.e., Mancozeb 75 WP @ 600-800 grams per acre mixed in 200 litres of water, before the disease appears or at the first sign of infection at 7-12 day intervals, or spray a combination of Metalaxyl 8% + Mancozeb 64% WP @ 500-800 grams per acre mixed with 200-250 litres of water and spray at every 7-10 day interval depending on disease pressure. The PHI (pre-harvest interval) period for mancozeb and metalaxyl + mancozeb is 7 days.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Early Blight in Tomato?

Remove and burn infected leaves to stop the spread. Follow label instructions and wear hand gloves and a mask while spraying for safety. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended fertilizer dose for ber orchards?
Final Answer: Fertilizer application in Ber should be adjusted based on the plant’s age to ensure optimal growth and fruiting. For mature plants above 4 years, increase the dose to 30–50 kg FYM, 500–750 g nitrogen, 250–300 g phosphorus, and 250–300 g potassium per plant per year. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the fertilizer schedule for grapes?
Final Answer: Fertilizer application in grapes should be based on the plant’s age and local practices, such as the ‘Bahar’ flowering system commonly followed in Haryana. For young plants up to 2 years, apply 10–15 kg of well-rotted farmyard manure (FYM) along with 25–30 g nitrogen, 20–25 g phosphorus, and 25–30 g potassium per plant annually. For mature plants above 3 years, increase the dose to 30–40 kg FYM, 100–120 g nitrogen, 50–60 g phosphorus, and 100–120 g potassium per plant per year. Nitrogen should be applied in three splits — before sprouting, after sprouting, and during berry growth — while FYM, phosphorus, and potassium should be applied before pruning, which is typically done in January under the Bahar system to induce flowering. Nitrogen can be supplied by 230–250 g urea, phosphorus by 312-375 g SSP, and potassium by 165–200 g muriate of potash (MOP) per plant annually.

Some of the improved varieties are HC 98-64, which is early maturing and drought-tolerant in nature. The yield is 12-15 quintals/acre of grains. Another variety is HC 5, disease-resistant in nature, and has a yield potential of 10-12 quintals per acre. Both varieties have a seed rate of 8-10Kg/acre.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended seed rate of Moong(Green Gram)?
Final Answer: The recommended seed rate of moong(green gram) in the zaid(summer) season is 10-12 kg per acre, and 20-25 cm row-to-row and 7-10 cm plant-to-plant spacing should be maintained. Sow summer moong within March; do not sow after this, otherwise your crop will be hampered due to the monsoon rain.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the sowing time of Okra crop
Final Answer: For okra, sowing is best done in two seasons: spring-summer (February–March) and kharif (June–July). Choose well-drained, fertile soil for healthy crop growth. Soak seeds in water for 6–8 hours before sowing to improve sprouting. Use only fresh, disease-free seeds for a strong crop stand. Timely sowing gives better yield and fewer pest attacks. Keep 1.5 ft row and 0.75 ft plant spacing. For early pest protection, treat seeds with Imidacloprid 600 FS @ 5 ml per kg of seed. This helps to reduce early sucking pest attack. All mentioned practices and inputs are approved for use in Haryana and help to ensure a healthy and productive okra crop.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the seed rate of Okra
Final Answer: For okra, use 4–5 kg of healthy, certified seed per acre for both summer and rainy seasons. Soak seeds in clean water for 6–8 hours before sowing to improve germination. Maintain row spacing of 45–60 cm and plant spacing of 15–30 cm for proper airflow and growth. Use resistant and high-yielding varieties like Hisar Unnat, Arka Anamika, or Parbhani Kranti, which are suitable for Haryana’s climate. You can buy certified seeds from local agri shops, FPOs, IFFCO, or authorized agri dealers such as the Haryana State Seed Certification Agency (HSSCA) or the Haryana Seeds Development Corporation (HSDC), to ensure better crop stand and pest tolerance. Avoid using old or damaged seed to prevent poor yield.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the fertilizer dose in Mango
Final Answer: For one mature mango tree, apply 50 kg of well-rotted FYM, 1000 grams of Nitrogen, 500 grams of phosphorus, and 1000 grams of potash every year. Give this dose in two parts - give the first dose during June–July before monsoon after pruning and mulching, and give the second dose in September-October before flowering. For young trees between 1-3 years, give only one-fourth of this dose. Always apply fertilizers in a ring shape about 1 to 1.5 feet away from the tree base and mix gently with the soil. After applying, give light irrigation immediately for better nutrient absorption. Avoid placing fertilizer directly at the base of the stem, as it may burn feeder roots or lead to nutrient loss. If possible, do a soil test at a nearby lab, or you can contact the KVK and Block Agriculture Office before applying fertilizers to know the exact need. Balanced fertilizer use helps the tree to give more flowers, bigger fruits, and better yield.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the best transplanting time for paddy?
Final Answer: Paddy (rice) is usually grown in the Kharif season, but transplanting may also be done during the Zaid season (summer months: March to May) under specific conditions, such as the availability of irrigation and the use of short-duration varieties. Avoid very long-duration varieties like traditional Basmati in the Zaid season due to water stress and high temperatures. Early transplanting (before 15 June) is generally discouraged by the Haryana Government to conserve groundwater. Permitted zones and transplanting dates are often announced for Direct-Seeded Rice (DSR) or early nursery raising, especially under water-saving campaigns (e.g., Mera Pani Meri Virasat). For Basmati varieties, transplanting can continue until mid-July.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the varieties of Pea
Final Answer: For pea cultivation during the Rabi season, the best variety for early harvest and market sale is Arkel, which matures in 55–60 days and yields around 32-40 q/acre. For higher yields, VL 7 and Pant Matar 3 are ideal mid-season varieties, maturing in 65–75 days with yields of 44–48 q/acre. If sowing is delayed or extended harvest is desired, Pb-89 is suitable, maturing in 80–85 days with a potential yield of 44–52 q/acre. Pea is not suitable for the Kharif season due to high temperature and humidity.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the suitable sowing time for the Jowar (Sorghum) crop?
Final Answer:
Jowar is grown as a kharif crop, and it is sown in the last week of June to the first week of July, aligning with the onset of monsoon rains.

The selection of Jowar depends on the purpose of growing the crop, and some varieties that have this sowing time are CSV 17, a good variety grown for grain purposes, and the yield potential of 10-12 quintals/acre. Another variety is CSV 20, which has drought and pest resistance and has a yield potential of 12-15 quintals/acre.

For getting fodder, Haryana Jowar-513 (S-513), with a maturation period of 95-105 days, having a high yield of 20 quintals/acre, is the most suitable variety.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Bottle gourd?
Final Answer: If you want to grow Bottle gourd for the summer, do the sowing in February–March so you can harvest early. For the Kharif season, sow in June-July to get a good crop.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended seed rate for Oats?
Final Answer: For sowing Oats as a fodder crop, use 40 kg of seeds per acre, and for a grain crop, use 32 kg per acre. From fodder Oats, you can expect around 200 to 240 quintals of green fodder per acre, depending on the variety and management. For grain production, the average yield is around 20 to 22 quintals per acre under good care and proper irrigation.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Is there any contact number for subsidy-related assistance

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding seed treatment in Sugarcane
Final Answer: For sugarcane seed treatment, where planting occurs in Spring (Feb-Mar) or Autumn (Sept-Oct), select healthy, disease-free setts with 2-3 buds. Dip the sets in a solution of Thiram 75% WP at 0.25% for 10–15 minutes to protect against fungal diseases like red rot and smut. For insect protection, add Imidacloprid 17.8% SL at 5 mL/L to control pests such as white grubs and termites. An optional hot water treatment at 50°C for 30 minutes can help control sett-borne diseases. Before planting, treat the setts with Azotobacter or Azospirillum biofertilizers to promote root growth. After treatment, allow the setts to dry in the shade before sowing. Use Bordeaux mixture for fungal protection in organic farming systems.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control manganese deficiency in Wheat crop?
Final Answer: If wheat leaves look pale with light yellow or grey spots, it may be due to manganese deficiency. To control it, mix 500 grams of manganese sulphate in 200 litres of water for each acre and spray in the early morning during cool weather. Do this once at 25–30 days after sowing. If symptoms show again, then repeat the spray after 10–12 days. Don’t spray during strong sunlight. This prevents weak growth and helps wheat develop better tillers and grain filling. Also, you can test your field soil by a nearby authorized lab, or you can contact your local KVK or Block Agriculture Office for a soil test to confirm the deficiency for better results.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the effective ways to control Fruit Borer in Tomato?
Final Answer: Fruit borer can cause serious damage to the Tomato crop, leading to a big reduction in yield if not managed in time. To control the adult moths, it is advised to install 5 pheromone traps per acre in the field. For biological control, you can release 50,000 eggs of Trichogramma chilonis per acre at weekly intervals, which helps in naturally reducing the pest population. If the infestation still continues even after these steps, then as a last option, you may go for a chemical spray using either Flubendiamide 20 WG at 40 grams per acre or Spinosad 45 SC at 60–70 ml per acre. Any one of the insecticides should be mixed in 200 litres of water and sprayed carefully on the crop. Harvest only after 5-7 days of spraying these insecticides. Early detection and timely action can help protect the tomato yield effectively.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control fruit borer attack in Moong (Greengram)?
Final Answer: Moong is not recommended as a Rabi crop. The suitable and profitable seasons for moong are the Kharif and Zaid seasons. Fruit borer damages flower buds, flowers, and pods in moong. It causes pod deformation, poor seed set, and yield loss. More active in flowering to pod formation stage during the rabi season in dry regions. To control fruit borer in moong, spray Emamectin Benzoate 5% SG @ 80 g per acre in 200 liters of water at the early pod formation stage. Use pheromone traps (5 per acre) to monitor pest levels, and spray in the early morning or evening for best results. Repeat after 10–12 days if needed. PHI for Emamectin Benzoate in pulses is 10-14 days. Ensure that there is at least this gap between spraying and harvesting to avoid pesticide residues in food grains.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control fruit dropping in the Cotton crop?
Final Answer: Fruit dropping in cotton can be a very serious issue because it can directly affect the yield of the crop. To manage fruit dropping in cotton, avoid heat and water stress at the time of boll formation, give balanced nutrients, and avoid excessive nitrogen, which can promote vegetative growth. Use mulching to retain moisture and give timely irrigation. If fruit dropping starts, Spray immediately growth regulators like Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 40-50ml/acre, Indole Acetic Acid (IAA) @ 20-25 mg/litre. Give Boron spray @ 1g/ litre of water to prevent deficiency and minimize the toxicity risk.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: When should the first irrigation be given to the Wheat crop?
Final Answer: Give the first irrigation in Wheat during the Crown Root Initiation (CRI) stage, which occurs around 20-25 days after sowing. This is the most important irrigation in the entire Wheat season. If water is not given at this stage, it can seriously affect root development and reduce your final yield. Timely irrigation here ensures strong crop growth and better harvest.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended dose of urea for the wheat?
Final Answer: Growing wheat in the Kharif (monsoon) season (June–July sowing) is not a standard practice because the hot, humid conditions and heavy rainfall are generally unsuitable for wheat growth and can significantly reduce yields. Wheat is primarily a Rabi season crop. Do not apply urea near the seed or in high concentrations to avoid seed damage. Split application of urea is crucial. Urea contains 46% nitrogen (N) and is used to meet the recommended dose for Rabi wheat . Standard dose is 60 kg N/acre( 130 kg urea), generally split in two roughly equal applications (half during sowing and the remaining half at the time of first irrigation. Standard practice is closer to 50% N at the CRI stage, 25% at tillering, 25% at booting/flowering.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Hoppers in Paddy?
Final Answer: Hoppers in Paddy suck the sap and drain the plant’s strength, turning lush green fields into patches of yellow known as hopper burn. To control hopper in your paddy crop, spray Acephate 75 SP (267-400 g/acre) or Acetamiprid 20 SP (20-40 g/acre) or Bifenthrin 10 % EC (200 ml/acre) or Buprofezin 25 SC (320 ml/acre). Mix any one insecticide in 200 liters of water and spray one per acre. Keep changing the insecticide every year to break the resistance in the pests. Stop the spray of chemical pesticides 15 days before harvesting the paddy.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control broad leaf weeds in Wheat crop?
Final Answer: If broadleaf weeds are seen in wheat, spray 2,4-D Amine Salt 58% SL at 344–516 ml mixed in 200 litres of water per acre. Apply this herbicide 20–30 days after sowing, when the wheat crop is at the 3–4 leaf stage and weeds are still young for best control. Always spray on a clear, dry day with no wind or rain forecast. Use a fan-type flat nozzle for even coverage on the weed foliage. Avoid spraying during strong winds or rainy weather to prevent drift and poor results. Clean the sprayer properly before and after use. Early and timely spraying gives the best weed control and ensures good crop growth. As an important note: Avoid spray drift to nearby crops like mustard or vegetables, as they are sensitive to 2,4-D.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the control measures for the deficiency of Zinc sulfate in Wheat crop?
Final Answer: If young Wheat leaves turn pale, growth slows down, and white patches appear, it may be zinc deficiency. For prevention, apply 10 kg Zinc Sulphate (21%) per acre in soil at sowing for proper root uptake. If symptoms appear after sowing, do foliar spray with 1 kg Zinc Sulphate and 0.5 kg slaked lime in 200 litres of water per acre at 25–30 days after sowing. Spray in the morning and cover the crop well. Repeat spray after 10 days only if symptoms continue. Use soil application for long-term effect, and foliar spray for quick recovery. Timely zinc use improves tillering, grain filling, and yield.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I manage powdery mildew in Wheat crop?
Final Answer: If white, powdery spots appear on wheat leaves or stems, it may be a sign of powdery mildew, a fungal disease that affects crop health and reduces yield. For control, spray Tebuconazole 25% EC @ 200 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Spray during clear, dry weather—avoid spraying in the evening or during rain. If needed, repeat after 10–12 days. To reduce disease risk, grow resistant varieties like WH 1105, WH 1124, HD 2967, or WH 1184, which are widely used by farmers This fungicide is approved for use as per CCS HAU and ICAR guidelines. Early take action and timely spray help to protect the crop and ensure better yield.  Alternatively, you may use Wettable Sulphur 80% WP @ 1.25 kg per acre. Both are scientifically validated and recommended by ICAR and agri universities.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the improved varieties of Wheat?
Final Answer: If you are planning to sow wheat in rainfed areas, then varieties like C 306, WH 1025, WH 1080, and WH 1142 are best suited. These can give you an average yield of around 16–18 quintals per acre, depending on rainfall and soil fertility. For irrigated conditions, go for high-yielding varieties like WH 157, WH 283, WH 147, WH 711, WH 1105, and WH 542. These varieties can yield around 20–24 quintals per acre with good crop management. If you are doing late sowing, then choose early maturing varieties like Raj 3765, WH 1021, and WH 1124. These varieties mature in a shorter time and still give good yields of 16–20 quintals per acre.And if you want to grow Durum Wheat (kathiya gehu), which is preferred by some buyers for suji and pasta, you can select WH 896, WH 912, or WHD 943. These can yield about 18–22 quintals per acre, provided proper nutrition and irrigation are given.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which are the improved varieties of Cotton crop?
Final Answer: For a profitable Kharif cotton crop, you should go with a Bt hybrid, which is known for good local performance. There are two main varieties, which are RCH 659 BG-II and MRC 7017 BG-II. These are in demand by farmers because they have a high yield of up to 10-12 quintals per acre and better tolerance to regional pests. Always buy your seeds from an authorized and trusted dealer.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the improved late-maturing wheat varieties suitable?
Final Answer: Late-sown wheat is typically sown from late December to the first week of January. You must choose varieties that have a shorter maturity period and good tolerance for heat. Late-sown varieties include WH 1270, PBW 435, UP 2425, Raj 3765, and PBW 373 give yield 18–22 quintals/ac depending on the soil fertility and cultivation practices. Select the right variety and provide proper irrigation, required nutrients, and weed control to give high yields and returns because when compared to time sown varieties It is important to note that yields under late sowing are usually lower than those from timely sowing in mid-November give high yields than late sowing varieties.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the varieties of Cotton
Final Answer: Cotton is typically sown during the Kharif season (April–May) under irrigated conditions. Recommended Bt cotton hybrids for the region include RCH-650 BG-II, MRC-7351 BG-II, NCS-855 BG-II, JKCH-1947 BG-II, and Ankur-3028 BG-II, which provide good yield potential and resistance to bollworms. The yield for these Bt hybrids generally ranges between 8–12 quintals per acre (20–30 q/ha), depending on the variety and growing conditions, with RCH-650 BG-II and MRC-7351 BG-II commonly yielding around 10–12 q/acre under optimal conditions. For non-Bt or desi cotton options, varieties like HD-123 and HD-432 are suitable for limited irrigation or organic farming systems. Among these, HD-123 typically yields about 9–10 q/acre under normal irrigated conditions. Additionally, F-1861, a popular American cotton variety (Gossypium hirsutum), is ideal for areas with sufficient water and conventional farming practices.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control False smut in Paddy?
Final Answer: During kharif, false smut in paddy appears as yellowish-green spore balls on grains, lowering yield and quality. To control it per acre, treat seeds with carbendazim 2 g/kg before sowing. Spray hexaconazole @ 200-400 ml per acre dissolved in 200 liters of water at tillering and pre-flowering stages. Alternatively, use Propiconazole 25EC @ 20 ml/acre. Maintain balanced nitrogen levels, remove infected plant debris, and practice early planting and crop rotation to reduce disease incidence.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Termites in Cotton crop?
Final Answer: In cotton, termites attack young plants by feeding on roots and stems near the soil surface, causing plants to wilt and die. Early signs include wilting seedlings and visible termite tunnels around roots. Adopt deep summer ploughing to expose termite colonies and use only well-decomposed FYM (not fresh manure). Keep the field clean by removing stubble and crop residues. Avoid over-irrigation, as moist soil favours termite activity. If infestation is noticed, apply imidacloprid 30.5% SC @ 50-100 ml/acre around the plant base or use fipronil 5% SC @ 600ml/acre as soil drenching, before sowing. Maintaining field hygiene by removing old crop residues and stubble helps reduce termite habitats. Also, avoid excessive irrigation, as moist soil encourages termite activity. These measures together help protect cotton crops from termite damage effectively.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control major pests in Cotton?
Final Answer: Cotton is a Kharif crop, and is not suitable to grow during the Zaid season (March–June). Cotton should be sown with the onset of the monsoon (June–July) for optimal growth and yield. Pests like aphids, jassids, and whiteflies can be managed by spraying Thiamethoxam 25 WG at 40.5 grams/acre or Imidacloprid 17.8 SL at 40-50 ml/acre. As the crop enters flowering and boll formation, bollworms (especially pink and spotted) may appear — control them using Emamectin benzoate 5 SG at 88 grams/acre or Indoxacarb 14.5% SC at 200 ml/acre. For mealybugs, spray Buprofezin 25 SC at 400 ml/acre. Use yellow sticky traps (10/acre) for whiteflies and pheromone traps (5/acre) for monitoring bollworms. Always spray with about 200 litres of water per acre and follow integrated pest management (IPM) practices for best results. Follow PHIs strictly to avoid residues and protect workers, for Thiamethoxam is 21days, Imidacloprid is 40 days, Emamectin Benzoate & Indoxacarb is 10–15 days, and Buprofezin is 14 days.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Can you provide information regarding the varieties of Wheat
Final Answer: During the Rabi season, top wheat varieties include HD 2967, HD 3086, WH 1105, WH 1270, and DBW 222. These are high-yielding (24–27 q/acre), rust-resistant, and suitable for timely or slightly late sowing. WH 1270 is a new variety from HAU Hisar with improved yield and disease resistance, while DBW 222 performs well under heat stress. Sowing is best done from late October to mid-November for optimal results.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which improved paddy varieties are recommended for the region?
Final Answer: Paddy is grown only as a Kharif crop. Some of the improved varieties sown during the Kharif season include HKR 47, which is tolerant to bacterial leaf blight and yields 28–32 quintals per acre. Pusa RH 10 is another variety with a high yield potential of 17.6 quintals per acre. CSR 30 is tolerant to salinity, and its yield potential is 12-14 quintals per acre. Another improved variety is PR 128, resistant to leaf blast, with an expected yield of 20–24 quintals per acre.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the mandi rate of Paddy?
Final Answer: As of August 8, 2025, mandi prices for Basmati paddy have ranged between ₹3,750 - ₹3,800 per quintal, while common paddy prices have varied from ₹3,200 to ₹4,145 per quintal, depending on quality and specific market conditions. However, mandi rates change daily and can fluctuate significantly. Reliable information is available on the Haryana State Agricultural Marketing Board (HSAMB) website (hsamb.org.in) or by calling the Kisan Call Centre at 1800-180-1551. Using these sources, along with local mandi platforms or apps, helps farmers make well-informed marketing decisions.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Sheath blight in Paddy?
Final Answer: In Kharif Paddy, sheath blight shows grayish-white lesions on leaf sheaths, causing rotting and poor grain filling. To control, avoid excess nitrogen, and maintain proper spacing. Treat seeds with Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 10 g/kg seed and apply it to the soil at 1 kg per acre 30 days after transplanting. Spray fungicides like Validamycin 3% L 400-500 ml per acre or Hexaconazole 5% EC 200-400 ml per acre at the boot leaf stage and repeat after 15 days. These fungicides should be mixed in 200 liters of water per acre. Keep fields clean by removing crop residues to reduce infection.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the fertilizer dose in paddy?
Final Answer: You should always do a soil test before applying fertilizers. It helps avoid overuse or underuse, which can harm the crop or soil. The Basal dose for paddy is Nitrogen (N) 60 kg, Phosphorus (P2O5) 24 kg, Potassium (K2O) 24 kg per acre. To achieve this, you need to apply fertilizers. Basal Dose (at or just before transplanting): Apply full dose of Phosphorus: 52 kg DAP and Potassium: 40 kg MOP, and give 1/3rd of Nitrogen: 35-40 kg Urea. Give first top dressing (3 weeks after transplanting): 1/3rd of Nitrogen: 35 kg Urea, and second top dressing (6 weeks after transplanting): 1/3rd of Nitrogen: 35 kg Urea.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the dosage of Urea in Paddy?
Final Answer: For Kharif paddy cultivation, the recommended fertilizer dose per acre includes 110 kg of Urea, providing 50 kg of Nitrogen (N), 27 kg of DAP (or SSP), 20 kg of MOP, and 25 kg of ZnSO₄, which supplies 9 kg of Zinc (Zn). The urea should be split into three equal doses: one-third applied at puddling as the basal dose, one-third at tillering (around 25 days after transplanting), and the final third at panicle initiation (around 45 days after transplanting). DAP, MOP, and ZnSO₄ should be incorporated during puddling. This balanced nutrient application ensures proper growth and maximizes yield during the Kharif season.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Leaf folder in Paddy crop?
Final Answer:
In the early stages of attack, use 750 ml of neem oil combined with 150 ml of soap solution in 200 liters of water.

In later stages, spray with Cartap Hydrochloride 4% GR by mixing 10 kg of granules with 10 to 15 kg of sand or ash, spread evenly over the paddy field. This process, known as broadcasting, should be done about 25–50 days after transplanting. Ensure light irrigation after application if the field is dry to help the granules dissolve properly.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the last irrigation in Wheat crop
Final Answer: Wheat is a major and long-duration crop where the last irrigation should be applied 15-20 days before harvesting, basically around mid-March for timely sown crops like those planted in Nov-Dec(late sown). This irrigation is helpful for the grain-filling stage and helps prevent yield loss due to heat stress during April's rising temperatures. But also take some precautions, like using light irrigation to avoid waterlogging, because at this stage, excessive moisture can cause lodging. Also, check your climatic condition; if suddenly unseasonal rains occur, it will cause lodging.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How  to control Sundi (armyworm or cutworm) in Wheat?
Final Answer: Sundi (cutworms or armyworms) can cause serious damage to Rabi-season wheat, especially during the early vegetative stages. For chemical control, foliar sprays such as Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC @ 1 ml/litre for cutworms and Alpha-cypermethrin 10% SC or Quinalphos 25% EC @ 2 ml/litre for armyworms are recommended. It is better to apply these sprays in the late afternoon or early evening. Cultural practices include deep ploughing, weed removal, and the use of neem-based biopesticides under biological control. Economic threshold: Apply control measures when 2–3 larvae per square meter are observed.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control control stemborer in Paddy crop?
Final Answer: Stem borer causes “Dead Heart”, where the central leaf dries and can be pulled out easily, and “white ear”, where the panicle turns white and empty. These symptoms happen because larvae bore into the stem, damaging the plant. To control it, clip seedling tips before transplanting, remove and destroy infested tillers and stubble, and install 4–5 pheromone traps per acre. Release Trichogramma japonicum @ 22,000 wasps/acre starting 10 days after transplanting, repeating weekly for 3 times. If infestation is severe (over 2% dead hearts), spray Cartap hydrochloride 4G @300g/ acre or Profenophos 50 EC @ 400 ml/acre in 100–120 liters of water. Maintain field hygiene and proper plant spacing for best results.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Insects in Paddy?
Final Answer: To control pests in the paddy crop during the Kharif season, you can focus on IPM strategies for major paddy pests like Stem Borer, Brown Planthopper (BPH), and Leaf Folder. These should include: Cultural practices - Use resistant varieties, practice timely planting, and adopt crop rotation. Mechanical control - Use light traps and pheromone traps. Biological control - Encourage and conserve natural predators and parasites such as wasps, spiders, and beetles. Chemical control - For Stem Borer: Cartap Hydrochloride 50% SP @ 400 g/acre in 200 L of water (repeat every 7-10 days if needed), PHI- 7 to 21 days. For BPH: Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 50-60 ml/acre in 200 L of water (repeat after 14 days if required), PHI- 7 days. For Leaf Folder: Chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC @ 60 ml/acre in 200 L of water (apply around 30 days after transplanting), PHI- 14 days.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the seed rate of Basmati Paddy?
Final Answer: The seed rate for Basmati paddy depends on the specific variety and the method of sowing. For nursery sowing, generally 8 kg of seed is sufficient to raise seedlings for transplanting one acre of the main field. But early maturing varieties like Pusa Basmati 1509, which have high tillering capacity, require only 5–6 kg per acre, while varieties like Pusa Basmati 1121 need around 7-8 kg per acre of main field for nursery preparation. For DSR (Direct Seeded Rice) in Basmati, the recommended seed rate is typically 8-12 kg per acre, depending on seed germination rate and soil type.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to Control Tella(Jassids/Leafhoppers) in Cotton Crop?
Final Answer: Jassid/leafhopper (Tela) infestation symptoms in cotton include yellowing and curling of leaf edges, a reddish or bronzed appearance on leaves, and, in severe cases, the leaf may dry. To control jassid/leafhopper (Tela) in cotton, an integrated pest management approach combining cultural, mechanical, biological, and chemical measures is recommended. Remove weeds in and around fields, as they can host leafhoppers; avoid planting cotton in the same field year after year; do not grow bhindi, moong, or arhar near or as a border crop; install yellow sticky traps to catch adults; and if infestation is mild, spray Azadirachtin 1500 ppm at 300-500 ml per acre in 200 liters of water in the early morning or late evening. If infestation is severe or you find curled leaves with 2 nymphs/adult per leaf, rotate insecticide spray of Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 60 ml per acre diluted in 200 liters of water or Diafenthiuron 50 WP @ 240 grams per acre mixed in 200 liters of water to prevent jassid resistance.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Tela (Jassids) in Paddy Crop?
Final Answer: Tela (Jassids) is not commonly found in paddy, but it can attack paddy during the summer season, particularly during hot and dry spells. They may damage young paddy crops by sucking sap. Its symptoms are leaf tips turning yellow and then brown, or you can see sticky honeydew on leaves. To control jassids in paddy, use tolerant varieties such as PR-126, Pusa Basmati 1718, or IR 64, and maintain proper spacing. If the threshold level is crossed, like if you see 5-10 jassids per hill at the vegetative stage or 10-20 insects during the flowering stage, you can spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 0.3ml/ litre or Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 0.25 g/litre or Flonicamid 50% WG @ 0.3g/g/litre of water. Repeat sprays at 10-15 day intervals if attacks are severe.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control the Leaf folder in the Paddy crop?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to prevent Iron and Nitrogen deficiency in Paddy nursery?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for the Basmati crop?
Final Answer: Basmati rice is a Kharif crop. It is sown with the onset of the monsoon in June-July and harvested in October-November. It is not grown as a summer crop. The recommended fertilizer dose for Basmati rice in your region during the summer season includes 24-30 kg of Nitrogen (N), 12-15 kg of Phosphorus (P₂O₅), and 12-15 kg of Potassium (K₂O) per acre. To achieve this dose, you can apply 40-50 kg of Urea per acre, split into 3 to 4 applications for better nitrogen use efficiency. The first dose of Urea should be given around 21 DAT, the second at 40 DAT, and the third at 60 DAT before panicle initiation. Phosphorus can be supplied through 25-35 kg of Di-Ammonium Phosphate (DAP) and Potassium through 20-30 kg of Muriate of Potash (MOP), both applied as a basal dose during transplanting. It is also beneficial to apply 2 tons of well-decomposed farmyard manure (FYM) during final land preparation to improve soil fertility and structure. A soil test is highly recommended before applying fertilizers to ensure balanced nutrition and avoid excess use, particularly of DAP, which can lead to nutrient imbalance and reduced zinc availability.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Wilt In Paddy?

The use of bakanae-tolerant varieties such as ‘CSR 36’ and ‘Pusa Basmati 1509’ is the first line of defence against bakanae in Haryana. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the seed rate of Wheat

Proper seed rate helps in achieving optimal yield and a healthy crop stand.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the seed treatment of Wheat

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the early varieties of Wheat

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: When is the first irrigation done in wheat crop?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizers are required for wheat?
Final Answer: Wheat requires nutrients in the form of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, typically supplied through urea, DAP (Diammonium Phosphate), and MOP (Muriate of Potash). The remaining half of the urea should be applied after the first irrigation, about 20–25 days after sowing. This split application of nitrogen ensures better nutrient uptake, reduces losses, and supports healthy crop growth. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Rats in Wheat crop?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control yellowing of leaves in Wheat crop?
Final Answer: Yellowing of leaves in your Wheat crop can happen due to different reasons like lack of nutrients, water stress, pest attack, or disease. You don’t need to worry, just check your crop carefully. If the yellowing starts from the bottom leaves and spreads upward, it may be due to Nitrogen deficiency; in such cases, applying Urea with irrigation can help. If the yellowing is seen mostly on the newer leaves, it could be a Sulphur deficiency, for which Gypsum or Sulphur-based fertilizer should be used. If the leaves show yellow and white stripes, then it's likely a Zinc deficiency, and spraying Zinc Sulphate 21% (2.5 g/l) with lime can help. If yellow patches appear in some parts of the field, check for termite damage at the base of plants or see if the soil is too dry or compacted, which may cause water stress. If you see yellowing with spots or powdery growth, it could be a disease like yellow rust, and spraying Propiconazole 25 EC (200 ml/acre) by mixing in 200-250 litres of water is recommended. Identifying the right cause early will help you take the correct steps to protect your crop.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Yellow Rust in Wheat?
Final Answer: Yellow rust in wheat appears as yellow-orange powdery streaks on leaves and can spread rapidly in the cool, humid weather of January-February, severely reducing your grain yield. While using resistant varieties like HD-3086 and WH-1105 is the best prevention, you must spray a fungicide at the very first sign of the disease. To manage resistance, rotate between effective chemicals like Propiconazole 25% EC at 200 ml per acre or Tebuconazole 25.9% EC at 200 ml per acre. Both of these are mixed in 200 -250 litres of water to ensure full coverage. For severe infections, a modern combination product like Azoxystrobin + Tebuconazole is also highly effective. For safety, you must observe the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of 30-35 days after spraying before harvesting the crop.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control yellowness in Paddy leaves?
Final Answer: Yellowing in paddy leaves may be due to several reasons, such as nutrient deficiency (nitrogen, zinc, iron, magnesium), water stress, and pest and disease attack, so proper diagnosis is key for control. If yellowing symptoms appear on older leaves on the lower side with poor tillering, then it is due to nitrogen deficiency. To correct this, apply urea at 35-50 kg per acre as top dressing, or you can apply a foliar spray of 2% urea solution (20 grams per litre of water). If yellowing appears on younger leaves while the veins remain green, it is due to iron deficiency. To correct this, use a foliar spray of ferrous sulphate 0.5% (5 grams per litre of water) 2-3 times at 15-day intervals. If yellowing symptoms appear on lower leaves with a brown, rusty appearance during the early stage, it may be due to zinc deficiency. To correct this, use a foliar spray of 0.5% zinc sulphate solution(5 grams zinc sulphate + 2.5 grams slaked lime per litre of water). Water stress or over-irrigation can cause yellowing in paddy leaves. To control this, maintain a 2-3 cm water level in the field, especially during the early growth stage, and avoid over-irrigation or long dry spells. If the symptoms are characterized by water-soaked spots that turn yellow along leaf margins and dry, then it may be due to bacterial blight disease. To control this, apply streptocycline (1 gram per 10 litres of water) + copper oxychloride (2-3 grams per litre of water).

 If the yellowing is observed as stripes, it is because of a disease known as Yellow rust, which is controlled by spraying Propiconazole 25 EC at 200 ml per acre in 200-250 liters of water.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Fruit borer in Brinjal?
Final Answer: Fruit borer in brinjal (Leucinodes orbonalis) is a big headache for farmers, as it makes small holes in fruits and also damages young shoots, resulting in a drop in yield, and the market price also goes down. If you want a good crop and a good income, you have to manage it from the start with full care. First of all, keep your field neat, regularly pluck and destroy damaged fruits and shoots so the pest cycle is broken. Never grow brinjal again and again on the same land; instead, rotate with maize, pulses, or wheat. Keep enough spacing in the field - around 60 cm between rows and 45 cm between plants within a row - so that air and sunlight reach plants properly. For natural control, release Trichogramma egg parasitoids @ 50,000 per acre once in 15 days; these tiny wasps kill fruit borer eggs themselves. Also, you spray Neem oil 1% @ 1200 ml per acre or NSKE (Neem Seed Kernel Extract) 5% @ 10 litres per acre. These are safe and reduce pests without harming beneficial insects. When pest pressure is high, use safe and recommended chemicals, as you can use Chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC @ 60 ml per acre in 200–250 litres water, it is very effective and safe for friendly insects. as an alternative also you can use Emamectin benzoate 5% SG @ 80-81 g per acre or Spinosad 48 EC @ 50 ml per acre in 200–250 litres water. Remember, PHI (waiting period before harvest) is 3 days and 3-4 days for Spinosad. Always rotate these chemicals; don’t repeat the same one, otherwise pests will become resistant. Treat seed with Trichoderma viride @ 4 g per kg seed, it saves plants from soil fungus and makes them stronger against soil-borne disease. Do soil testing in your KVK or JNKVV lab so you can apply fertilisers properly, and healthy plants tolerate pests much better. If we follow all these steps together - clean field, crop rotation, neem and Trichogramma for bio-control, and take timely action, then fruit borer can be controlled very well. Always check the field regularly, spray on time, and never overdose. This way, our brinjal crop will stay healthy, the fruits will be clean, and you will get a good yield and profit.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Yellow Mosaic in Moong(Green gram)?
Final Answer: Yellow mosaic disease (YMD) in moong fields comes because of a virus spread by whitefly insects. Once a plant gets it, the leaves show yellow patches, growth stops, pods remain empty, and yield goes down badly. For protection from the start, treat the seed with Imidacloprid 600 FS at 5 ml per kg of seed, and also with Trichoderma viride at 4 g/kg of seed to keep seedlings strong. For chemical control, you can apply a foliar spray of Imidacloprid 17.8 SL at 50 ml per acre in 100–125 liters of water or Thiamethoxam 25 WG at 40 g per acre, or as an alternative, you can also use Acetamiprid 20 SP at 30 g per acre, both of these mixed in 150–200 liters of water for even spraying. Do spray at 15 and 30 days after sowing, and repeat only if whiteflies are seen. Spray early morning or evening to save pollinators, and keep a 15-day gap, and for Imidacloprid 17.8% SL on pulses, it is 21 days before harvest after the last spray, but also follow the withdrawal period label as mentioned. Along with this, spray neem oil (2 ml per liter of water) or NSKE 5% to reduce whitefly safely and cut down on chemicals. Always do soil testing at KVK or a university lab and follow balanced fertilizer, because excess nitrogen makes crops weak and pest attacks heavy. If you keep your fields clean, rotate crops, use resistant varieties, treat seeds, add neem, and, if needed, spray approved chemicals in time, then yellow mosaic disease can be managed well, crops will stay healthy, and yields will be safe.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Termites in Wheat?
Final Answer: In our wheat crop, the termite problem is very dangerous, because these insects eat roots and stems from inside, and plants start drying patch by patch. Even after good sowing, you may get a poor stand and low yield. To control them properly, first follow clean and timely farming—don’t leave old stubbles and weeds in the field, use only well-rotted manure, do timely sowing instead of late sowing, and if possible, rotate wheat with non-host crops like pulses or oilseeds. This reduces termite buildup. Along with that, mix neem cake at 100 kg per acre in soil at sowing; it not only repels termites but also improves soil health. For seed safety, always do seed treatment—either with Chlorpyriphos 20 EC at 6 ml/kg seed (but applied only under expert guidance as it has some restrictions), or, for a modern, safer option, you can use Bifenthrin 10 EC at 6 ml/kg seed or Imidacloprid 600 FS at 2 ml/kg seed. This gives early-stage protection. For standing crops, the best is to apply Fipronil 0.3% granules at 10 - 12 kg per acre in soil at sowing time; it stays longer and protects plants throughout. If a termite attack still appears later, apply Chlorpyriphos 20 EC at 1.0 to 1.2 liters per acre, mixed in about 200 to 250 liters of water, sprayed on soil around the base of wheat plants for termite attack control, and for localized soil application, the typical dose is 1.2 liters per acre mixed in 50 kg of moist soil and broadcast near the root zone, when adjusted for area. (but applied only under expert guidance, as it has under some restrictions), Also, as an alternative for this purpose, you can use Deltamethrin, about 40–60 ml per acre, depending on how heavy the termite pressure is. Mix this well and spray with 200–250 liters of water per acre so that the soil around plants gets fully wet. The correct method is to do it as a soil drench or band spray near the root zone, because termites stay underground and feed on roots; it is safe, and sometimes it's used for combined IPM. If you do light irrigation after spraying, the medicine goes deeper into the soil and gives a better kill. Always remember to wear gloves and a mask (PPE) while mixing and spraying, and never spray in very hot weather because the crop can get stressed. Also, keep at least a 30-day gap (PHI) between the last spray and harvesting to keep the grain safe, and follow the withdrawal period on the label. For biological safety, treat the seed with Trichoderma viride at 4 g/kg seed, which makes the seedlings stronger and reduces soil-borne issues. Also, do soil testing at KVK or university labs every 2 years, because balanced fertilizer keeps the crop healthy and less prone to termite attack, while excess nitrogen makes the soil attractive for pests. If we manage in an integrated way—clean field, timely sowing, neem cake, resistant practices, seed treatment, proper control method—then termites can be kept fully under control, and you can get a strong plant stand, healthy crop, and good wheat yield with less tension.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Thrips in Chilli?
Final Answer: In our chilli crop, the thrips (Scirtothrips dorsalis) are very dangerous; they suck the sap from leaves and young fruits, which makes leaves curl, fruits get scars, and the yield goes down badly. To control them properly in Madhya Pradesh fields, it is best to follow a mixed approach—cultural, biological, and chemical control methods. First, keep the field clean and remove weeds around the crop because weeds give shelter to thrips. Also, avoid chili after sorghum since thrips increase there. Intercropping with agathi (Sesbania) also helps. For natural protection, apply neem oil 1500 ppm at 2 ml per liter of water spray and use Katyayani Triple Attack bio agent at 2 liters per acre, spraying with 200 to 250 liters of water per acre for good coverage. These reduce thrips without harming the soil. For seed safety, treat the seed with Trichoderma viride at 4 g/kg seed before sowing, so plants start strong. Now, for strong attacks, chemicals are needed, but you should rotate to avoid resistance. The best and safest spray is Spinosad 45% SC at 55–65 ml per acre in 200–250 liters of water (maintain PHI 7 days). If pressure is high, spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL at 40–50 ml per acre mixed in 200-250 liters of water. For dual action and as an alternative, you can use Katyayani Nashak (Fipronil 40% + Imidacloprid 40% WG) at 40–60 g per acre in 200–250 liters of water, which works both by contact and systemically and also controls whiteflies along with thrips. Another good option against resistant pests is Diafenthiuron 40.1% + Acetamiprid 3.9% WP at 200–250 g per acre mixed in the same volume of water. Spray well on both sides of the leaves. Always keep a PHI gap of 7–10 days for Imidacloprid 17.8% SL and Diafenthiuron 40.1% + Acetamiprid 3.9% WP in chilies before harvest (and 15–30 days for heavy products like Fipronil mixes (Fipronil 40% + Imidacloprid 40% WG) if the label says so). Also, for soil health, apply neem cake in the soil and do soil testing at the KVK or JNKVV lab for balanced fertilizer, because healthy plants tolerate thrips better. So, following these easy steps, like combining clean fields, neem and bio agents, seed treatment, and timely rotation of sprays, you can keep thrips under control, fruits will be clean and shining, and yield will be high.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to increase milk production in Buffalo?
Final Answer: If you want more milk from buffalo, you have to take care of three main things: good feeding, proper health, and right management. First of all, for feeding, always give green fodder in a good amount, like maize, bajra, cowpea in kharif and berseem in rabi, provide 1 kg of concentrate feed for every 2 to 2.5 litres of milk produced, in addition to the maintenance ration, because these give both protein and energy. If you grow improved varieties like cowpea Pusa Vishal, berseem Jaypee Super, or maize HQPM1/HQPM4, then the buffalo gets better nutrition, and milk increases naturally. Along with this, feed some concentrate mixture with oil cakes and grains, and keep a urea molasses mineral block (UMMB) in the shed, so buffalo can lick and digest better. A regular mineral mixture with calcium, phosphorus, zinc, and selenium must also be given because minerals directly affect milk flow. Nowadays, bypass protein and bypass fat supplements (like Megalac) are also available. If given 100 g–200 g daily with feed, it helps buffalo to produce more milk without weakness, but only under veterinary guidance. For health care, never miss vaccination and deworming as told by NDVSUV vets and give as per vet guidance, because if the buffalo is free from worms and disease, then she eats properly and converts feed into milk. Keep the shed clean, give fresh water always, and in summer, provide shade or a cool water bath, because stress reduces milk. For breeding, use artificial insemination (AI) with good Murrah or Bhadawari semen from government centres, so that the next generation is high-yielding. Along with this, feeding probiotics and yeast culture is also useful to improve digestion and rumen activity, which also pushes milk upward. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Semilooper in Soybean?
Final Answer: In our soybean crop, the semilooper is a very dangerous problem; its small green larvae eat the leaves from the edge and make big holes, and when the attack is more severe, the whole field looks like jali. The crop cannot do photosynthesis properly, and the yield goes down badly. To fight this pest, it is best to use integrated control—cultural, biological, and chemical—all together in the right way. First thing, keep the field clean, remove weeds and old crop residue where these larvae hide, and do summer deep ploughing so that the pupae inside the soil come out and die in the sun's heat. Rotate soybean with other crops like chana or wheat, and if possible, sow soybean at the proper time so that the peak attack period is avoided. For a biological way, use Bt powder (Bacillus thuringiensis var. kurstaki) spray at 300–400 g per acre in the early stage; this kills small larvae safely, and also neem seed kernel extract (NSKE) 5% spray is very effective for early populations. Along with this, natural enemies like spiders, wasps, and ladybird beetles also control larvae, so avoid unnecessary spraying, which kills these friends. If the pressure is high, then you can spray Profenophos 50 EC 500 ml per acre in 200 liters of water (0.125% solution) or Chlorpyriphos 20 EC 400 ml per acre (0.1%) (applied only under expert guidance, as it hassome restrictions), and as an alternative, Quinalphos 25 EC 200 ml per acre can be used in the same way. Always spray uniformly, covering both sides of leaves, and remember the 15–20 day pre-harvest interval before harvesting. For a safer alternative, use emamectin benzoate 5% SG at 12-15 g per acre in 200 liters of water or chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC at 100-120 ml per acre in 200 liters of water. If infestation is severe, repeat the spray after 10-15 days, covering both leaf surfaces uniformly. Maintain a pre-harvest interval (PHI) of 15-20 days before harvesting. Before sowing, treat soybean seeds with Trichoderma viride 4 g/kg seed to keep plants healthy from the start, and do soil testing in the KVK/JNKVV lab to apply balanced khad, because a strong plant resists pests naturally. By following these steps, you can easily control this pest and save your crop, and get a high yield.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control weeds in Wheat crop?
Final Answer: In the wheat crop, weeds eat fertilizer, water, and sunlight before our crop can take them, so the yield goes down. That is why proper weed control is very important. First of all, always use clean seed that is free from weed seeds, and do timely sowing so that wheat grows fast and suppresses the weeds. In summer, do one or two deep ploughings so that the weed seeds and roots come up and die in sunlight, and you can also use the stale seedbed technique — wet the soil to germinate weeds and then kill them before sowing. Crop rotation and keeping the field clean are also very useful. In biological methods, mulching with residues keeps weeds suppressed, and wheat varieties with better ground cover also check weed growth. In chemical methods, you can use a combined herbicide like Clodinafop-propargyl and  Metsulfuron-methyl (25 + 1.5 g per acre) and Sulfosulfuron and Metsulfuron-methyl (12 + 0.8 g per acre), which control both grassy and broadleaf weeds. If grassy weeds are heavy, you can use Isoproturon 400 g/acre or Clodinafop 60 ml/acre. Among new and safer options, Pinoxaden 75 ml/acre works very well, and for broad-spectrum control, Sulfosulfuron 12–15 g/acre is effective; all of these you can mix with 200-250 liters of water to ensure even spraying. For early weed prevention, Pendimethalin 1 litre/acre as a pre-emergence spray is very useful, mixed in 200 - 250 liters of water. Always spray 20–30 days after sowing and stop spraying at least 30 days before harvest to keep the crop safe. Seed treatment is also important — coat seeds with approved fungicide to ensure healthy crop emergence, and get soil testing done from KVK or JNKVV labs to apply the right balance of fertilizer, because a strong crop can naturally suppress weed pressure. By following these steps, your field will remain clean, the crop will grow fast, and the wheat yield will be high.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Stem borer in Paddy?
Final Answer: In paddy crops, the stem borer is a very dangerous pest because it makes dead hearts and white ear heads, and that cuts our yield badly, so you have to fight it from the start with a full mix of methods. First, use resistant varieties like CR Dhan 802, IR50, Chandina, CR Dhan 308, and Jayantidhan because they are tested and recommended by JNKVV, RVSKVV and ICAR-NRRI. Then do deep summer ploughing so the pupae come out in the sun and die. Before transplanting, clip the tips of seedlings to remove egg masses. Also, keep removing and burning dead hearts from the field, keep the water level proper, not stagnant, and put 4–5 light traps per acre to catch moths at night. For the release of Trichogramma japonicum cards at 20,000/acre every week during egg-laying season, you can also spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) at 200–250 g/acre in 200 litres of water to kill small larvae. Or use neem seed kernel extract 5% made fresh at home. If the pest is still heavy, then go for chemicals. In that case, you can use Cartap Hydrochloride 4% GR at 4–5 kg/acre, broadcast at 20–25 days after transplanting, followed by irrigation. Or, as an alternative, you can also use Chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC at 40–60 ml/acre in 200 liters of water for strong systemic control. If the infestation is still high, then you can use Fipronil 5% SC at 300–400 ml/acre spray in 200 litres of water, which is good for high infestation. Always spray between 20 and 30 DAT (days after transplanting) when the pest is active and use 200–250 liters of water per acre for uniform coverage. Never repeat the same chemical every time, but rotate them. Always spray only when dead hearts cross 5%, and keep in mind harvest safety gaps like Cartap 21 days, Chlorantraniliprole 20 days, Fipronil 21 days, and Phorate 30 days. Also, treat seeds with approved chemicals and do soil testing at KVK and authorized labs so plants stay strong. If you follow this integrated way with resistant variety, summer ploughing, light traps, neem, and Trichogramma, plus the correct chemical in the right dose and time, then the stem borer will stay under control, and the paddy crop will give you a good green yield without loss.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control flower dropping in Papaya?
Final Answer: In papaya crops, flower dropping happens due to many reasons together, mainly due to water stress (either drought or waterlogging), nutrient imbalance (lack of nitrogen, boron, calcium, and potassium; then the plant cannot make strong flowers, especially boron and calcium deficiency directly breaks fruit setting), unfavorable weather (cold, heat 20–33°C with 70–85% humidity, strong winds), poor pollination, pests and diseases (thrips, aphids, mites, mildew, and ring spot), and wrong practices (poor drainage, excess fertilizer or pesticide, and too many male plants). First thing, keep watering regularly and evenly, neither too much nor too little, especially in the flowering stage, and make sure the field has good drainage. Also, protect plants from strong winds with barriers and do light pruning of extra branches so the plant does not take stress. Also, keep the orchard clean and remove weeds, and if it is the dioecious type, then remove extra male plants after pollination. For nutrition, foliar spray Boron 20% EDTA at 1 g per liter of water (200 liters per acre) at flowering and fruit set time, and if calcium or zinc deficiency is present, then give Zinc Sulphate 100 g per acre (0.5 g/liter) along with this mix. Add half the quantity of slaked lime to prevent leaf burn and mix with 200 liters of water per acre for full leaf coverage. For boron deficiency, you can use Borax Spray 200 g per acre (0.1 g/liter) with 200 liters of water per acre. Also use Azospirillum + Phosphobacteria. Apply 20 g per plant at planting and again at 6 months; for typical papaya density (900–1000 plants/acre), use 18–20 kg/acre of each. Mix well-rotted FYM/compost and broadcast in the root zone, or use as a soil drench with plenty of water. If pests like thrips, aphids, or mites attack, then spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL 40-60 ml per acre (0.7–1 ml/liter) with 200 liters of water per acre. If a fungal disease like powdery mildew comes, then spray Mancozeb 75 WP 400 g per acre in 200 liters of water per acre for full coverage on leaves/stems. Do not use growth regulators without expert advice; it is better to depend on nutrition and irrigation. Before sowing, treat the seed with Trichoderma viride 4 g/kg seed to prevent fungal disease and soil-borne disease. Always test soil in the KVK or JNKVV lab to balance nutrients, especially boron, calcium, and zinc. For varieties, go with Red Lady, Pusa Dwarf, CO-7, Arka Prabhath, and Madhubindu, which have shown good fruit retention and yield in MP. Always remember to spray in the early morning or evening for better effect, follow the correct dose and water volume per acre, rotate chemicals if sprays are repeated, and maintain a harvest gap of 10–14 days after spraying. Other Tips: Intercrop with flowering plants (e.g., marigold, sunflower) in papaya rows and keep 1–2 honeybee boxes per acre for better fruit set. If you follow these steps, then your papaya will keep more flowers, set more fruits, and give you good profit with a healthy orchard.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control fruit borer in bitter gourd?
Final Answer: In the bitter gourd (Karela) crop, the fruit borer is a very dangerous pest because it goes inside the fruit, makes holes, and spoils the quality, so production and income both come down. If you manage it early with a mix of methods, then the problem will stay under control. First thing, always keep the field clean—pick and destroy damaged fruits, do deep plowing after harvest so that pupae die in the sun, rotate crops and avoid growing karela again and again in the same field, and use trap crops like ribbed gourd to divert borers. Second, go with biological methods—spray about 1 liter of neem oil per acre mixed in 200 liters of water. Spray regularly for effective control and coverage. Use Trichogramma cards if available, and apply as an alternative. Abamectin 1.9% EC 150 ml per acre in 200 liters of water for selective control. If the infestation gets high, then you can use Spinosad 45% SC. 60–90 ml per acre in 200–250 liters of water, or as an alternative, you may use Chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC spray at 60 ml per acre in 200–250 liters of water, or Lambda-Cyhalothrin 4.9% CS. 100–200 ml per acre in 200–250 liters of water in the same way by foliar spray, and as a new modern alternative, you can use Broflanilide 300 g/L SC 15–34 ml per acre mixed in 200 liters of water. But always rotate between them to avoid resistance. Fourth, install pheromone traps (5–6 per acre) to catch adult moths and reduce the population naturally. Fifth, remember PHI rules—Spinosad and Abamectin need 7 days, Chlorantraniliprole 3 days, Broflanilide 1 day, and Lambda-Cyhalothrin 5 days' gap before harvest so that fruits stay safe for market. Along with this, use healthy seed, do soil testing in the KVK or JNKVV lab, and keep nutrition balanced with proper manures and fertilizers to make plants strong against pests. If you follow these steps, then the fruit borer will not spread much, the fruits will stay clean, and the karela crop will give a good yield and income.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the varieties of Coriander?
Final Answer: Coriander is a very profitable crop, but the season and variety choice make a big difference in yield and income. In the Jayad season, the best sowing time is March-June. Coriander grows nicely when there is moderate temperature and some humidity. At this time, varieties like Rajendra Swati from JNKVV give very good results because they are resistant to stem gall and powdery mildew, give around 12–14 quintals of seed per acre, and have a strong aroma. Along with this, Suguna (LCC-236) is also good—it finishes in 90–95 days, has high essential oil content, and gives both seed and green leaf, so it is a double benefit. Another option is Suruchi (LCC-234), which gives more green leaves, approximately 18.2 quintals per acre or 1.82 tonnes per acre, and can be grown even in the off-season, so it fits well in Jayad also, and approximately 61–73 quintals per acre in the rabi season with proper management. But, if you want to grow in the Rabi season, then the best sowing time is mid-October to mid-November; coriander gives maximum yield because of the cool climate. And if you want to grow in the Kharif season, then the best sowing time is July-August. The same varieties, like Rajendra Swati, Suguna, and Suruchi, plus CO-1 and CO-2, perform well. In Rabi, crops mature in 90–110 days, and yield can go up to 10 quintals per acre due to better seed setting. For both seasons, the seed rate is 8–10 kg per acre, and spacing should be maintained at 30 cm between rows and 10–15 cm between plants to ensure proper growth and airflow. Harvesting time is 90–110 days, depending on the variety. When cultivated using scientific techniques, irrigated crops produce 6.1–7.3 quintals of seeds and 40.5–50.6 quintals of leaves per acre, whereas unirrigated crops produce 2.0–2.8 quintals per acre. Before sowing, prepare the seedbed well with light harrowing, treat the seeds with Trichoderma at 4 g/kg to avoid seed-borne diseases, and do soil testing at the KVK or JNKVV lab for proper nutrition. Crop rotation with cereals or pulses also helps keep soil healthy. If you choose the right varieties and the right method, then the coriander crop will be healthy, give a strong aroma, have a high seed yield, and have a good market rate.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control hopper in Mango?
Final Answer: Mango hopper is a dangerous pest for mango trees because it sucks juice from tender shoots and flowers and makes sticky honeydew, and from that black sooty mold comes, due to which flowers drop and fruit set becomes weak, so if you control it in time, then yield will surely increase. First, do cultural work like pruning in July–August to keep branches open so sunlight and wind can enter and the hopper does not get a dense, shady place; also, keep the orchard clean by removing infected twigs and leaves, avoid too close planting, and use drip irrigation instead of flood irrigation because over-wetness gives the hopper a chance to multiply. Second, the biological way is also strong—keep natural enemies like ladybird beetles and green lacewings, and spray the bio-fungus Metarhizium anisopliae, which kills hoppers naturally without harming beneficial insects. For chemical control, you can use Imidacloprid 17.8% SL 40-60 ml per acre in 200 liters of water during flowering for a systemic and long-lasting effect, or spray Lambda-Cyhalothrin 5% EC 100 ml per acre in 200 liters of water for quick knockdown. In heavy attacks, you may use Chlorpyriphos 20% EC 500 ml per acre mixed in 200 - 250 liters of water (use only under expert guidance, as it has some restrictions), a broad-spectrum chemical effective for heavy infestations, or Cypermethrin 25% EC 200–300 ml per acre mixed in 200 - 250 liters of water, an effective pyrethroid for quick action on hoppers. As a modern alternative option, you can use Thiamethoxam 25% WG 40–50 g per acre or a mixture of Thiamethoxam and Lambda-Cyhalothrin 125 ml per acre mixed in 200–250 liters of water, which gives both systemic and contact effects. Along with this, Neem oil 3% solution (1 liter of neem oil in 200 liters of water) is eco-friendly and safe before harvest. Always remember to keep a 15-day pre-harvest interval after chemical spray, but for neem, which is generally safe, it varies; use a 7-day interval before harvest, and for thiamethoxam on mango, it's 30 days. Spray only when the hopper count is more than 5–6 per inflorescence, and do the spraying in the early morning or evening for better effect. Rotate medicines for resistance, and every year, do soil tests in the KVK or JNKVV lab and give balanced fertilizer, especially nitrogen and potash, to keep trees strong. If you follow this integrated method of cultural, biological, and chemical control, then mango trees will stay healthy, hopper attacks will be under control, fruit set will be strong, and harvest will surely give more returns.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control aphid in coriander?
Final Answer: Aphids are small sap-sucking insects that attack coriander crops. They make leaves curl, plants look weak, and release a sticky honeydew, which brings black sooty mold, reducing seed and leaf yield badly. If not managed in time, bhai, they can spoil the whole crop. If you want to manage it, first keep the field clean, remove old residues, do crop rotation with cereals or pulses, and use mulching or intercropping with marigolds to reduce landing of aphids, and keep proper spacing (30 cm row to row, 10–15 cm plant to plant) so airflow is good. To protect natural friends like ladybirds and lacewings, which eat aphids. You can also use bio solutions like Lecanicillium (0.5–1 kg) or Beauveria bassiana (1–2 kg in 200 liters of water), with no PHI, which is fully safe and works well in humid conditions. Also, you can spray Neem-based Azadirachtin (10,000 ppm)—200 ml per acre in 200 liters of water, which is safe and eco-friendly, or Trichogramma 1–2 lakh (100,000 to 200,000 parasitoids) per acre release is also good, which controls eggs, is used as a biocontrol agent, and is released directly. If the attack becomes high, then go for a chemical spray like Spinosad 75 ml or Imidacloprid 40-60 ml mixed in 200 liters of water, sprayed when the aphid population crosses the economic threshold (~5 aphids/plant). As an alternative, you may use Thiamethoxam 25% WG at 40 g per acre mixed in 200 liters of water, which is another effective option. For a safer option, you may use Azadirachtin 10,000 ppm (Neem-based) at 200 ml per acre in 200 liters of water for eco-friendly control and spray in the morning or evening when aphids are active and repeat sprays at 30-35 day intervals or as per pest monitoring. For extra safety, do seed treatment with Thiamethoxam 5 FS at 5 g/kg seed with polymer coating, and beneficial microbes like Azospirillum (120 g/kg seed) and Trichoderma viride (4 g/kg seed) provide early protection. After chemical spray, wait at least 7 days for Spinosad 45% SC and Azadirachtin 10,000 ppm (Neem-based), Imidacloprid 17.8% SL, and Thiamethoxam 25% WG. Keep a 15-day gap before harvest, don’t allow excess moisture in the field, and apply balanced fertilizer as per the soil test so that plants stay strong. If you follow this, aphid damage will remain very low, and you will get healthy seeds and fresh green leaves of coriander with good profit.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control flower and fruit dropping in jackfruit?
Final Answer: Flower and fruit drop in jackfruit happens due to hormone imbalance, drought stress, nutrient deficiency, pest or disease pressure, and weather fluctuations. It greatly reduces yield and farmer income. But with some simple and correct steps, you can control it and save yield. First, keep regular irrigation during flowering and fruit set, don’t allow drought stress, and use mulching to hold soil moisture. Also, protect trees from cattle damage, and do light pruning so that light and air can reach properly. Second, keep soil healthy by seed treatment or root application of Trichoderma viride. 6-10 ml per kg of seed; coat seeds uniformly and shade dry before sowing for root health and disease suppression. For soil application: use 2 liters per acre mixed in 200 liters of water for drenching around tree roots or in fields, and for another application practice, enrich 1 ton of farmyard manure (FYM) with 1 to 2 kg of Trichoderma powder and then spread it across one acre (especially for horticultural crops, and doses depend on plant age) if needed for fungal disease control, and apply fertilizers as per soil test because balanced nutrition reduces drop. For chemicals, you can use foliar spray NAA (naphthalene acetic acid) 20 ppm at 20–40 ml per acre in 200–250 liters of water at the pea stage and fruit formation, and it is even better to combine 5 liters of NAA 20 ppm and 4–5 kg of urea 2% per acre in 200–250 liters of water to increase fruit weight and retention, or in some cases use NAA 10 ppm + 2,4-D 10 ppm at 5 liters per acre in 200–250 liters of water, which helps in fruit set. Always spray early morning or evening for better absorption, and repeat at the flowering and pea stages if required, and remember to keep a PHI of 15 days before harvest for all chemicals. Along with this, keep the orchard clean, don’t give excess irrigation, and protect beneficial microbes for root health. By following these steps, flower and fruit dropping in jackfruit will reduce, the fruits will stay on the tree till maturity, and you will get a heavy yield with better profit.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control flower droping in Chilli?
Final Answer: Flower drop in chilli is mainly caused by temperature extremes, water stress (both excess and deficiency), nutrient imbalance (especially nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium), and pest attack like thrips and aphids. but if you manage step by step, then flower drop can be reduced, and the yield will improve. First thing, keep soil moisture balanced with drip irrigation, avoid waterlogging, and put mulch so the soil remains cool. When flower drop is high use chemical options like you can use NAA (Naphthalene Acetic Acid) 20 ppm 15-20 ml per acre at flowering initiation to reduce flower drop and balanced hormone and for sucking pest spray Chlorfenapyr 10% SC or Abamectin 1.9% EC @ 150 ml per acre in 200 litres water for thrips and mites or as an alternative you may use Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 40 g per acre in 200 litres water, it also works well for sucking pest. For aphid control, if infestation is high, then you can use Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 40-60 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Always spray in early morning or evening for best absorption, use recommended water, and rotate chemicals so resistance does not develop. By following the steps, flowers dropping in chilli will come down, fruits will set properly, and you will get a strong crop with more yield and profit.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control leaf curl in chilli?
Final Answer: Leaf curl occurs due to whiteflies in chili. They suck sap from leaves and cause curled leaves and transmit chilli leaf curl virus disease, so it is important to control them early to reduce yield loss. To control leaf curl in chili, remove weeds and infected plants early, use resistant varieties like Punjab Lal, Arka Nihita, etc., use yellow sticky traps (10-12 per acre), release natural predators of whiteflies like Chrysoperla spp., spray neem oil at 5 ml per liter of water, and if the infestation is severe, spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL at 60 ml per acre mixed in 200 liters of water or Diafenthiuron 50 WP at 240 grams per acre mixed in 200 liters of water. Rotate insecticides every 10-12 days to avoid resistance. In Chile, for imidacloprid, a 40-day PHI (pre-harvest interval) and for diafenthiuron, a 7-day PHI period are mandatory.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I manage Flower droping in my Brinjal crop?

To control it, you should start with balanced nutrition, focusing on key micronutrients that support flower and fruit development, like boron, which is crucial for pollen growth. Use a product like Solubor (0.5-1.0 gm/liter of water). Apply this spray during the pre-flowering stage and repeat every 15 days. For a supply of calcium and other micronutrients, use a water-soluble mixture (2-3 gm/liter of water). Also, pest control is essential, as insects like borers directly damage flowers. For the shoot and fruit borer, use a biological control like Trichogramma wasps. Release around 50,000 wasps per acre at weekly intervals. If chemical control becomes necessary, use an insecticide like Spinosad at 0.3 ml/liter of water. For an acre, use 60 to 70 ml in 200 to 250 liters of water with a 3-5 day interval period. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Sucking pests in my Gram crop?
Final Answer: Sucking pests are a major threat to the Urd cultivation, causing damage by extracting sap and transmitting viral diseases. The primary sucking pests in Urd are aphids, jassids (leafhoppers), and whiteflies. You can start with prevention by selecting varieties that are resistant or tolerant to pests and diseases. Recommended resistant/tolerant varieties for cultivation in Madhya Pradesh include Pant Urd 31, Pant Urd 35, IPU 94-1, and Mash 414. Always use certified, disease-free seeds of these improved varieties. Prepare the field properly by removing all weed hosts and crop residues from previous seasons. Practice crop rotation with non-legume crops like cereals to break the pest life cycle. Ensure proper spacing between plants to avoid a crowded canopy that favors pest buildup. Monitor the crop regularly from the early vegetative stage for signs of pest activity. Look for yellowing leaves, hopper burn, sticky honeydew, or sooty mold. Use yellow sticky traps placed around the field to monitor and trap flying adult pests. If pests are detected below economic threshold levels, use botanical insecticides. A spray of neem oil at a rate of 3 to 5 ml/liter of water can be effective. For aphids and jassids, a spray of imidacloprid 17.8 SL is effective at 0.3 to 0.5 ml/liter of water (60 ml of imidacloprid in 200 liters of water). For whiteflies and thrips, a spray of diafenthiuron 50 WP is recommended at 0.4 to 0.5 gm/liter of water (240 gm in 200 liters of water). Another effective chemical for a range of sucking pests is thiamethoxam 25 WG at 0.2 to 0.3 gm/liter of water. (40 gm in 200 liters of water) with a 7 - 10 day interval period.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding Fisheries
