QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the accessories of honeybee rearing?
Final Answer: If you want to start honeybee rearing, the first thing you need is some good accessories that make the work easier, safer, and more productive. The basic items are: Beehives (wooden or plastic frame type), each frame having a Top Bar Length of 48.3 cm (19 inches), Height of Side Bars 23.2 cm (9 1/8 inches), and Width of Side Bars 3.5 cm (1 3/8 inches), with foundation sheets where bees build their comb. Protective clothing, including bee suit, veil, gloves, and boots, so you can work without fear of stings.A hive tool, a small iron tool used to open and handle frames. A smoker, which produces smoke to calm the bees when opening the hive. Tools for queen management, such as a queen cage and queen excluder. A honey extractor, which removes honey without breaking the combs. Optional: a pollen trap to collect pollen for extra income. All these tools help you work smoothly with bees and get more honey with less trouble. To keep bees healthy, always keep the hive area clean and dry (cultural control), use beneficial microbes when possible (biological control), and only use safe chemicals under expert advice. These tools are available in agricultural markets, bee equipment shops, government cooperatives, and also from TNAU Bee Research Centre or Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs). Starting with good accessories and proper training makes honeybee farming safer and more profitable.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended varieties of Bhindi (Okra)?
Final Answer: Bhendi (Okra) is grown as a Zaid season crop rather than in the Rabi season, as low temperatures are not suitable for its growth. On average, 3–4 kg of seed is required per acre. Some varieties of Bhendi include: PKM 1: Matures in 45–50 days, produces dark green, smooth fruits, and has a high yield potential of 45–50 quintals per acre. Arka Anamika: Matures in 50–55 days, is tolerant to Yellow Vein Mosaic Virus, has good keeping quality, and a yield potential of 45–50 quintals per acre. Hybrid variety COBhH-3: Resistant to Yellow Vein Mosaic Virus, has slender dark green pods, and a yield potential of 80 quintals per acre. Bhendi Hybrid CO 4: Provides 22 harvests in 110 days starting from 39 days after sowing, is resistant to Bhendi Yellow Mosaic Virus, and has a yield potential of 128 quintals per acre. COBhH-3 (another hybrid): Resistant to Yellow Vein Mosaic Virus, with a yield of 88 quintals per acre.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control White rust in Amranthus?
Final Answer: White rust in amaranthus is caused by a fungus. Symptoms appear as white pustules or blister-like structures, mainly on the undersides of leaves, which may also show yellowing, curling, and premature dropping. To manage white rust, always follow a crop rotation cycle and use early-maturing varieties like Arka Harita, which are resistant to the disease. Initially, apply Neem oil (Azadirachtin 1%) at 3 ml per liter of water (600 ml in 200 liters per acre). If the disease persists, spray Mancozeb 75% WP at a dose of 600–800 grams per acre, repeating the application after 10 days if needed. Maintain a waiting period of 7–10 days before harvest to avoid contamination.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control button shedding in coconut?
Final Answer: Button shedding in coconut is a major cause of yield loss, where young coconut flowers or small nuts (buttons) drop prematurely. It is caused by water stress (drought or waterlogging), nutrient deficiencies—especially potassium and boron—high temperature and humidity fluctuations, or hormonal imbalance in the palm. To control button shedding: Apply about 1–2 kg of potassium fertilizer (K₂O) per palm annually, split into doses during the growing season to support fruit retention. Spray a 0.1% borax solution as a foliar spray at flower initiation and button formation stages to supply essential boron. Use Alpha Naphthyl Acetic Acid (Planofix 4.5% SL) at 1 ml in 4.5 litres of water. Typically, 2–3 sprays at 15-day intervals during button formation help reduce premature fruit drop. Maintain a 7–14 day interval before harvest after spraying. Control of Rhinoceros beetle is also essential, as it can contribute to button shedding. To manage this pest, spray 0.03% chlorpyrifos (1.5 ml per litre of water; total 300 ml in 200 litres per acre). Observe a pre-harvest interval of 14 days.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for Top dressing in Plants?
Final Answer: Top dressing fertilizer management is essential for optimizing yields in major crops. For rice during the Kharif season, it is recommended to apply about 92 kg of urea in 3 split doses during active tillering, panicle initiation, and during the heading/booting stage as top dressing. Mop is applied at active tillering and Panicle initiation stage with 17 Kg at each stage as top dressing. For cotton varieties under irrigated conditions, a total of 40 Kg of Nitrogen, 20 Kg of Phosphorus, and 20 Kg of Potash(Urea 87 kg, SSP 125 kg, and MOP 33 kg). After 40-45 days, 45 kg of urea and 16 Kg of MOP are applied as top dressing. After 60-65 days remaining 40 40Kg of urea and 17 Kg of MOP should be applied as top dressing.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the suitable annual intercrops to cultivate?
Final Answer: In a Kharif or Rabi season rice-based cropping system, cowpea sown at 5 kg/acre alongside dry-seeded lowland rice, using varieties CO(Gg) 7 or VBN 1, serves as green manure. It enriches soil fertility when incorporated into the soil at 45 DAS, providing nitrogen equivalent to 35–40 kg N/acre. Black gram variety VBN 8 (6–8 kg/acre) and red gram variety VBN 3 (2–3 kg/acre) can also be intercropped with rice to improve soil nitrogen content, yielding 80–100 kg/acre pulse grain worth ₹6,000–7,000, without reducing rice yield. In a groundnut-based cropping system, black gram variety VBN 8 and cowpea variety VBN 3, at a seed rate of 8–10 kg/acre, can be grown as intercrops in a pattern of 6 rows of groundnut plus 1 row of pulse intercrop. This provides an economic benefit of 80–100 kg/acre intercrop grain (equivalent to ₹5,000–6,000), along with 20–25 kg N fixed (valued at ₹700–800). In a cotton-based cropping system, intercropping cotton with pulses or cluster bean at a 2:1 ratio is recommended for better returns. Cluster bean variety Pusa Navbahar (5–6 kg/acre), cowpea variety VBN 1 (5–6 kg/acre), or black gram variety VBN 8 (6–8 kg/acre) should be planted in a pattern of 2 rows of cotton followed by 1 row of intercrop. The intercrops can yield 200–250 kg/acre of grain or vegetables, providing extra income of ₹8,000–10,000, along with nitrogen fixation worth ₹1,000–1,500 in fertilizer savings.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the spacing required for Singunia?
Final Answer: The proper spacing for Singunia (Syngonium), as recommended by Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU), is approximately 30 cm × 10 cm or 30 cm × 30 cm, depending on the cultivation purpose and variety. Experiments have also been conducted with spacings like 60 cm × 10 cm and 60 cm × 5 cm to suit mechanization, but generally, a spacing of 30 cm between plants and 10–30 cm between rows is followed for good growth, healthy development, and nutrient uptake. Proper spacing ensures adequate sunlight, air circulation, and overall plant health. Maintain regular irrigation every 15–20 days, and harvest green manure plants 45–60 days after sowing.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Brown Plant Hopper in paddy?
Final Answer: Rice is grown as a  kharif and rabi season crop and not preferable to be  grown as a zaid season crop. Brown Planthopper can be initially controlled by avoiding avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer as it promotes lush growth, which attracts BPH. Ensure to maintain proper plant spacing. Install yellow sticky traps 8–10 traps per acre just above the crop canopy, evenly distributed in the field. It is installed for monitoring nymph and adult activity. Light traps are installed at later stages during night to monitor and reduce adult populations. As a chemical control Imidacloprid 17.8% SL 40-50 ml in 200 liters of water is recommended. As an alternative Fipronil 5% SC 400 ml/ac is recommended for an acre. Alternate the chemicals to resistance build up. A waiting period of 14-21 days is needed to avoid contamination.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Smut disease in Sugarcane?
Final Answer: Sugarcane smut disease is caused by a fungus. One of the most effective ways to manage the disease is by planting sugarcane varieties resistant to smut, such as CO 86032, CO 86031, and CoC 671. Before planting, treat sugarcane setts with hot water at 50 °C for 30 minutes to kill any latent smut spores. This treatment helps reduce the initial inoculum load in the field. Sett treatment should also be carried out by immersing sugarcane setts in a fungicidal solution of Triadimefon (1 g per 1 liter of water) for 10 minutes before planting. This practice helps control the disease at the planting stage. In cases of severe infection, foliar sprays of fungicides such as Propiconazole (1 ml per 1 liter of water; total 200 ml per acre) may be applied to control the spread of the disease. The pre-harvest interval for Propiconazole in sugarcane is around 30 days, which must be strictly followed.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to prepare Jeevamrutham?
Final Answer: Jeevamrutham is used as a bio-fertilizer and soil conditioner to enhance soil health and provide nutrients to crops naturally. It can be applied by diluting with water (usually 10–20 liters of Jeevamrutham per 200 liters of water) and spraying on crops or drenching the soil. It is prepared by mixing 10 kg of fresh cow dung with 5 liters of cow urine and 1-2 kg each of jaggery (or sugar) and 1-2 Kg of pulse flour (such as green gram or chickpea flour) in a large container. To this mixture, add a handful of garden soil collected from the farm to introduce beneficial microbes. Add sufficient water to make a smooth slurry and stir the mixture thoroughly. Cover the container and keep it in a shaded, cool place for about 3 to 6 days to allow microbial fermentation and multiplication. The Jeevamrutham is ready to use when it develops a pleasant sour smell and frothy texture, indicating active microbial growth. This bio-fertilizer can then be diluted and applied to crops to enhance soil health and provide natural nutrients. The entire 200-litre batch is typically sufficient to apply to one acre of land, either by drenching the soil or by releasing it with irrigation water.  For a foliar spray, a 10% solution that is 10 litres of Jeevamrutham mixed in 90 litres of water is the standard recommendation.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended varieties of Samba rice?
Final Answer: Samba varieties are sown during the months of August to September rather than for the Zaid season. Some of the Samba varieties suitable for the Villupuram region are ADT51, ADT52, CR1009 Sub1, CO50, and TRY3. ADT 51 is a medium-slender variety with a duration of 155–160 days, yielding about 2645 kg per acre. It has high milling recovery (70.3%) and head rice recovery (60.5%) and is resistant to blast, while moderately resistant to leaf folder, stem borer, sheath blight, and sheath rot. ADT 52 matures in 145–150 days with a similar grain type and yields around 2450 kg/acre, showing resistance to gall midge and moderate tolerance to leaf blast, neck blast, grain discoloration, and bacterial leaf blight. CR 1009 Sub1 is a short, bold grain variety with a medium duration of about 120 days, yielding approximately 2430 kg/acre. It is moderately resistant to brown spot, blast, BPH, and WBPH, and is tolerant to early-stage submergence for 10–14 days. CO 50, a medium, slender, white, fine-grain variety, takes around 150 days to mature and yields about 2680 kg/acre. It is moderately resistant to several pests and diseases, including stem borer, leaf folder, gall midge, blast, sheath blight, and brown spot. TRY 3 is a medium-duration variety (130–140 days) with medium-bold white grains, yielding 2430–2630 kg/acre. It is salt-tolerant and moderately resistant to major pests and diseases, making it well-suited for saline-affected areas.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the duration time of ADT 39 variety of paddy?
Final Answer: ADT 39 is grown as a Kharif and Rabi season crop, and it is categorized as a short-duration rice variety, common for the Kar, Kuruvai, and Sornavari seasons. It usually matures in about 120-125 days. It is resistant to blast and sheath rot, is semi-dwarf, and has a yield potential of 24-25 quintals per acre under good management.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Powdery mildew in Rose plant?
Final Answer: The symptoms of powdery mildew are white to grayish powdery fungal growths that appear mainly on the upper surfaces of leaves, stems, and sometimes on buds and flowers. Leaves may curl, distort, and eventually turn yellow or brown. At the appearance of initial symptoms, spray neem oil prepared by mixing 5 ml of neem oil with 1 liter of water, along with 2 ml of soap. For field-scale application, mix 500 ml of neem oil and 150 ml of soap in 200 liters of water. Repeat the spray after 7–14 days if needed. In case of severe infection, apply Propiconazole at 1 ml per liter of water and repeat as necessary. Follow a Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of 7–14 days to avoid contamination. Re-entry into the field is allowed once the pesticide has dried on the foliage.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for Cashew plant?
Final Answer: Cashew trees require a balanced fertilizer application to support their vegetative growth and fruit development. A total of 60 trees can be planted per acre with a spacing of 8 m × 8 m. The nutrient requirement per tree is 42 kg DAP, 81 kg urea, and 75 kg MOP per year. In the first year, apply 1/5th of this quantity (8 kg DAP, 16 kg urea, 15 kg MOP); in the second year, apply 2/5th, and increase proportionally each year to reach the full dose from the fifth year onwards. Fertilizers should be broadcast in a 0.5–3 m radius around the tree and incorporated by light raking. These fertilizers should be applied in two equal split doses: one during June–July and the other during October–November. This split application helps in efficient nutrient uptake and supports the tree’s growth during critical phases. Fertilizers should be applied in a circular trench around the tree, extending from the base to the drip line, ensuring that the nutrients reach the active root zone.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for Arecanut plant?
Final Answer: The amount of fertilizer required is DAP 26–34 kg, urea 76–95 kg, and MOP 20–26 kg per acre. These nutrients should be applied in split doses, with one-third of the nitrogen and the full dose of phosphorus and potassium applied at the onset of the Kharif season to support early growth. The remaining nitrogen should be applied in two equal splits—one after three months and the other after six months. Along with chemical fertilizers, it is beneficial to apply 25–30 tons of well-decomposed organic manure, such as farmyard manure or compost, annually to improve soil health. Fertilizers should be evenly spread around the base of the palms, keeping a distance of about one meter from the trunk to avoid root burn, followed by adequate irrigation to enhance nutrient uptake.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the System of Rice Intensification Techniques?
Final Answer: System of Rice Intensification (SRI) is best suited for seasons with assured irrigation. Difficulty in crop establishment may be seen in areas with heavy downpour. The seed rate is 7-8 kg for a single seedling per hill. A single seedling of 15 days old is transplanted per hill following a square planting of 25 x 25 cm. Later, fill up the gaps between the 7th and 10th days after transplanting. Transplant within 30 minutes of pulling out the seedlings. Irrigation should be done only to moisten the soil in the early period of 10 days and restore irrigation to a maximum depth of 2.5 cm after the development of hairline cracks in the soil until panicle initiation. Weeding has to be done using a rotary weeder or Cono weeder and moving the weeder with forward and backward motion to bury the weeds and also to aerate the soil at 7-10 day intervals from 10-15 days after planting in either direction of the rows and columns.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the estimated yield of Alphonso?
Final Answer: Alphonso mango is a fast-growing variety of mango. The seed rate is 60 saplings per acre under 8 m × 8 m spacing. It is usually propagated by grafting. Alphonso trees start bearing fruits from the 5th year after planting. The yield in the initial years is generally low, but from the 5th year onwards, it reaches around 88–100 quintals per acre, depending on variety and climatic conditions.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the suitable sown season in Crossandra?
Final Answer: Crossandra (Crossandra infundibuliformis L.) is sown from July to October. In Tamil Nadu, two main types are cultivated: tetraploid varieties, such as Orange, Lutea Yellow, and Sebaculis Red, and the triploid variety, Delhi Crossandra. Rooted cuttings of Delhi Crossandra are used for planting. The average yield is about 8 quintals per acre for tetraploid varieties and 11 quintals per acre for the triploid variety.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of Oil extracting method in Medicinal plants?
Final Answer: Farmers can extract oil from medicinal plants like lemongrass, tulsi, and neem using simple methods such as hydrodistillation and steam distillation. For example, lemongrass leaves can be boiled in water, and the steam carries the oil, which is then cooled and collected. Similarly, tulsi leaves can be steamed to release their essential oil. The correct method for neem oil is cold pressing the kernels, which produces pure oil for commercial use. For small-scale farmers, Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) is a practical solution—crush the kernels, soak them in water, and use the liquid as a natural pesticide.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the loans available in Cooperative society?
Final Answer: Farmers can access agricultural loans through the Kisan Credit Card (KCC) scheme, offered by Primary Agricultural Cooperative Credit Societies (PACS). The collateral-free loan limit under KCC is ₹1.6 lakh, which can be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other inputs. For sugarcane, loans are provided based on land area, covering up to 10 acres. Medium-term loans (3–5 years) are also available for purchasing tractors, irrigation pumps, or livestock. Loans carry low interest rates, and farmers who repay on time may receive interest subsidies from the government. The KCC is the main loan product supporting farmers’ financial needs for agricultural activities.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the yield of Brinjal?
Final Answer: Brinjal cultivation during the Kharif season (June to September) can be highly productive if managed properly. The Kharif season, characterized by heavy rainfall, requires selecting brinjal varieties that are rain-tolerant and capable of withstanding waterlogging and fluctuating weather conditions. For Kharif brinjal cultivation, high-yielding, rain-tolerant varieties should be prioritized. Local varieties such as Co-2, PKM-1, and MDU-1 are reliable, yielding around 100 to 120 quintals per acre. However, hybrid varieties like Neelam, Annamalai, and Arka Anand perform significantly better in the Kharif season. These hybrids are more pest-resistant and better suited to the rainy conditions, with potential yields ranging from 240 to 320 quintals per acre. To achieve high yields, farmers should ensure proper irrigation (especially in the early stages), implement effective pest control, and conduct regular harvesting every 4–5 days, starting around 55–60 days after planting. By following these practices, farmers can achieve consistent and high yields throughout the Kharif season.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Fruit borer?
Final Answer: During the Kharif season, crops like brinjal, okra, and chillies are prone to attacks by fruit borers, which bore into young fruits, causing visible holes filled with black frass and leading to premature fruit rot or fall. To manage these pests, farmers should regularly remove and destroy infested fruits and use pheromone traps (4–5 per acre) to monitor and trap adult moths. For organic control, Neem oil 3% at 600 ml/acre or NSKE 5% at 5 kg/acre can be sprayed every 10–12 days. In cases of heavy infestation, chemical control options include Emamectin Benzoate 5 SG at 80 g/acre (3–4 day PHI), Flubendiamide 480 SC at 60 ml/acre (5-day PHI), or Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC at 60 ml/acre (22-day PHI). Sprays should be applied in the evening to minimize harm to beneficial insects and repeated every 10–12 days while adhering to the specific PHI to ensure food safety. Regular monitoring, along with an integrated use of these methods, helps farmers keep fruit borers under control and protect their crops during the Kharif season.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Leaf spot?
Final Answer: During the Zaid season, crops like brinjal, tomato, and chillies often suffer from leaf spot disease, which appears as brown or black circular spots on the leaves. These spots can merge, causing the leaves to yellow and fall off, reducing plant strength and yield. To manage this disease, farmers should remove infected leaves, avoid overcrowding, and maintain good field hygiene. For effective control, spray Mancozeb 75% WP at 600–800 g per acre or Copper Oxychloride 50% WP at 800 g–1 kg per acre in 200 litres of water, at intervals of 10–12 days. In severe cases, Tebuconazole 25.9% EC at 200–250 ml per acre can be used. Always observe a Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of 7 days for Mancozeb and Copper Oxychloride, and 3 days for Tebuconazole to ensure a safe harvest. Following these steps helps protect crops from leaf spot while keeping the produce safe for consumption.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the medicinal plants?
Final Answer: The favorable climate and fertile soil offer great potential for cultivating medicinal plants like Musa paradisiaca (plantain), Trianthema portulacastrum (Saaranathi), Vinca rosea (Nithiyakalyaani), and Vitex negundo (Notchi). Plantain is propagated using suckers and requires spacing of 1.8–2.4 meters, yielding around 10–12 tons per hectare. Saaranathi, which is used for stomach pain relief, grows well in well-drained soils and produces 1–1.5 tons of dried roots per hectare. Nithiyakalyaani and Notchi are grown for their medicinal leaves, which yield 1.5–2 tons of dried leaves per hectare. These plants benefit from organic fertilizers and pest control, such as neem oil. With a growing demand for medicinal herbs in the local and global markets, prices for these plants range from ₹500 to ₹15,000 per kilogram, depending on the species. By combining traditional knowledge with modern agricultural practices, farmers in Sivaganga can turn medicinal plant cultivation into a sustainable and profitable business.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bud rot in coconut?
Final Answer: Bud rot in coconut palms is most severe during the Kharif (monsoon) season. Symptoms include yellowing leaves, rotting of the central bud, and a foul smell, leading to the death of the palm crown. The disease thrives in humid, waterlogged conditions. To manage bud rot, first clean the crown by removing infected tissue, then apply 1% Bordeaux mixture (100 g copper sulfate + 100 g lime in 10 liters of water) at 500-1000 ml per palm before the monsoon and repeat every two months. For dwarf varieties, place 2 g mancozeb sachets in the leaf axils during rains. For young palms, apply Trichoderma asperellum (25 g per soil application) and spray Bacillus subtilis (10 g per liter of water) for fungal control. By combining these methods, farmers can effectively manage bud rot and protect their palms during the Kharif season.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the foliar spray for Casuarina?
Final Answer: During the Kharif season, Casuarina trees benefit from foliar sprays to boost growth and improve nutrient uptake. A micronutrient mixture containing zinc, iron, manganese, and boron should be applied at 200–250 ml per acre to enhance nutrient availability and tree health. To promote healthy shoot growth and reduce leaf drop, apply Calcium nitrate with magnesium (Calsan-MG) at 300–400 ml per acre. For boron enrichment, a boron-based liquid spray at 100–150 ml per acre helps strengthen cell walls and enhances resilience. Additionally, marine extract-based bio-stimulants (e.g., Tag Exotica) can be applied at 100–150 ml per acre to improve stress tolerance and encourage vigorous growth. Apply these sprays early in the morning or late evening, every 15–30 days, avoiding rainy weather for optimal absorption.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I subscribe to the Uzhavarin Valarum Velanmai magazine from TNAU?
Final Answer: Uzhavarin Valarum Velanmai is a Tamil monthly magazine published by the Directorate of Extension Education at Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU), Coimbatore, since 1975. The publication aims to provide farmers across Tamil Nadu with practical agricultural knowledge, covering important topics such as crop planning, pest management, organic farming, and updates on government schemes. The magazine is distributed through key agricultural institutions like the District Agricultural Office (DAO) and the Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) located at the TNAU Agricultural Research Station in Vrinjipuram, Tiruvannamalai, which are part of TNAU’s outreach efforts. Farmers can access the magazine by collecting it directly from these centers or can subscribe by sending a demand draft to the TNAU Directorate of Extension Education. The annual subscription fee is typically ₹100, though farmers should confirm the exact amount with the local office or TNAU’s website.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to contact machinery department?
Final Answer: The Agricultural Engineering Department in Tiruvannamalai plays a crucial role in supporting farmers with modern machinery and equipment. Headed by the Assistant Executive Engineer, the department offers services such as machinery maintenance camps, equipment demonstrations, subsidies, and access to the e-rental scheme. A recent machinery maintenance camp in Isanya Maidan showcased tractors, harvesters, and mobile repair units. Over the past four years, the department has distributed more than ₹21 crore worth of equipment, including sugarcane harvesters, electric motors, and solar-powered pumps, benefiting over 1,600 farmers. Additionally, the e-rental scheme allows farmers, especially smallholders, to rent machinery at subsidized rates. For subsidy applications, farmers can now apply online through the TNAgriNET portal, which is the unified platform for all machinery subsidy requests in Tamil Nadu. For inquiries or offline support, farmers can visit the Agricultural Engineering Office at Venkikal Village, Tiruvannamalai, or email aedeetvm@tn.nic.in.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for CO43 Variety at 30th day of crop?
Final Answer: CO 43 is a salt- and submergence-tolerant rice variety developed in Tamil Nadu, recognized for its fine quality and suitability for both raw and boiled rice. It matures in 135-140 days and is used in breeding programs for varieties with enhanced submergence tolerance. At 30 days after sowing (DAS), when the rice reaches the active tillering stage, it’s crucial to apply 26 kg of urea per acre (providing 12 kg of nitrogen) and 20 kg of muriate of potash (MOP) per acre (providing 10 kg of potassium (K₂O)). Phosphorus should already have been applied as a basal dose during planting. If zinc deficiency symptoms, such as yellowing leaves, are noticed, a 0.5% zinc sulfate foliar spray should be applied. This nutrient schedule is specifically recommended for the Kharif season, as CO 43 is not typically cultivated during the Jayad season in Tamil Nadu.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the Mullai varieties - CO1 and CO2?
Final Answer: Mullai varieties CO 1 and CO 2 are not cultivated during the Zaid season but are typically planted in the monsoon season, from June to August. CO 1 is a secondary clonal selection, yielding 41 quintals per acre, and is primarily used for oil extraction due to its pink-tinged buds. CO 2, developed from CO 1, yields 50 quintals per acre and has bolder buds, making it ideal for garland making. A crucial practice in jasmine cultivation is pruning, usually done in the last week of November to regulate plant growth and ensure a concentrated flowering season. Regular weekly irrigation is sufficient under normal conditions to maintain healthy growth.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended fertilizer dose for a paddy nursery for transplanting?
Final Answer: For a paddy nursery during the Kharif season, the fertilizer application for a 20-cent nursery (which is sufficient to transplant one acre of paddy) should include 40 kg of DAP (Diammonium Phosphate). This should be applied during the preparation of the nursery bed to provide essential phosphorus for strong root development and nitrogen for initial seedling growth. And 17 kg of urea should be applied 10 days after sowing, which helps to supply the required nitrogen for healthy seedling growth and early-stage vigor. These applications are in line with TNAU's recommended practices for efficient nursery management and optimal seedling development, ensuring that the nursery can support healthy plants for transplanting into the main field, covering one acre.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Ergot diseases in Pearl millet?
Final Answer: Ergot disease is a major concern in Cumbu (pearl millet) crops. Symptoms usually appear during and after the flowering stage, starting with sticky honeydew on the infected earheads, followed by the formation of dark, horn-like sclerotia that replace the normal grains. To manage ergot, soak seeds in a 2% salt solution (20 g of salt per liter of water) to remove infected seeds, then wash and dry them thoroughly before sowing. Practice crop rotation to avoid monocropping and reduce disease buildup. For foliar treatment, instead of Carbendazim, use a modern, safer fungicide such as Tebuconazole 50% + Trifloxystrobin 25% WG at a dose of 80–100 g per acre. Apply the fungicide at the 50% flowering stage for effective protection. It is essential to follow the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) specified on the product label to ensure crop safety and avoid harmful residues.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: From where can I get Tree killer?
Final Answer: Tree Killer is a chemical developed by Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) to control unwanted trees and shrubs in places like temple premises, rooftops, and canal bunds. It is effective but highly toxic and available only at TNAU, Coimbatore—making it impractical for most farmers. A more accessible and recommended method is the cut-stump technique, where the tree is cut near the base and a concentrated solution of Glyphosate 41% SL (mixed 1:1 with water) or 2,4-D Sodium Salt is applied immediately to the fresh cut. These systemic herbicides kill the roots and prevent regrowth. They are safe when used correctly, affordable, and easily available in local pesticide shops—making them a more practical choice for farmers across Tamil Nadu.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: From where can I get Durian?
Final Answer: If you want to plant durian, the safest source of seedlings is TNAU-approved nurseries and government horticulture farms. The most reliable source is the State Horticulture Farm at Burliar in the Nilgiris, located on the Ooty–Coimbatore highway, where farmers can obtain healthy, certified saplings. Other state horticulture farms across Tamil Nadu, including the State Horticulture Farm at Kallar, also supply certified durian and other tropical fruit plants. Always buy certified planting material, as it ensures true-to-type trees, better growth, and disease-free yield. Using uncertified saplings may result in poor growth, low yield, and pest problems. For current contact information, Burliar Farm can be reached at 04233-224995, or you can visit the official website: https://tnhorticulture.tn.gov.in. Farmers can also consult TNAU Horticultural College, Coimbatore, or their local KVK for guidance and training. Follow the TNAU package of practices, including proper manuring, irrigation, and disease management, to control fungal infections and promote healthy growth. By obtaining certified saplings and following TNAU recommendations, farmers can achieve healthy trees and good income from this high-value fruit within a few years.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to rear Kaadai (quail)?
Final Answer: If you want to rear Kaadai (Japanese Quail) in Tamil Nadu, it is really a good choice because these small birds grow fast, give quick income, and need very little space. Farmers here mostly go for the  Japanese quail variety (Coturnix japonica) which lays around 250 eggs per year and gives good meat yield. You can rear them any time in the year, but the best results and market price usually come in the post-monsoon season (October to March). For housing, you can keep them in a deep litter system with 1 sq ft per bird or in multi-tier cages to save space. Give approximate total feed consumption is 500-600 grams per bird to reach market weight. For breeding, keep one male with 3–4 females. Small farmers can easily start with 200–500 chicks per batch, and within 4–6 weeks, the birds reach a market weight of about 200–250 grams. For egg production, it is essential to provide a 14-16-hourthe  daily lighting schedule. Egg laying starts by 6 weeks, with eggs weighing 9–13 grams, and if you manage well, the livability is around 95%. Always buy chicks only from TANUVAS Veterinary College, Namakkal, or government-approved centers, because local uncertified chicks often give poor yield. For management, keep the well, the house clean and dry (cultural control), use probiotics in feed for strong immunity (biological control), and if any disease comes, use approved medicines but only with the vet’s advice. The eep temperature is around 25–30°C and humidity 50–70% for best growth. Give balanced feed with maize, soymeal, and other protein supplements, plus always provide clean water. If you follow these steps, you will get good egg and meat yield, less mortality, and a steady income from Kaadai farming.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the incubation period of Duck?
Final Answer: For ducks the incubation period is 28 days, and this is the same for common breeds like Khaki Campbell which many farmers in Tamil Nadu rear. The Muscovy duck has a much longer incubation period of 35 to 37 days. You can either let a broody duck sit and hatch naturally, or you can use an artificial incubator if you want more control and a higher hatch rate. In incubators, keep the temperature around 37.2–37.5°C (99–99.5°F) and maintain proper humidity. For the first 25 days, keep wet-bulb temperature near 30–31°C (86–88°F), then slightly increase to 33°C (90°F) in the last 3 days. Always turn eggs every hour and from day 2 to 25, sprinkle a little lukewarm water mixed with sanitizer to keep shells moist and clean. On day 7, do candling to check if embryos are growing, and by day 25, shift eggs to the hatcher. After hatching, ducklings need brooding for 3–4 weeks, starting with around 32°C (90°F) temperature and then slowly reducing. Keep clean water of 2–3 inches the depth so they can drink and play but not drown, and give balanced starter feed. For health, keep the incubator and brooding area always dry and clean (cultural control), use probiotics in water to build immunity (biological control), and if any infection comes, consult a vet and use medicines only as vet guidance. If you follow these simple steps, you will get a good hatch rate, healthy ducklings, and more profit from duck farming in Tamil Nadu.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is meant by incubator? how it is used in Animal husbandry?
Final Answer: An incubator is a specially designed device that provides the right temperature, humidity, and ventilation to hatch eggs artificially without a broody hen. It helps hatch eggs of chickens, ducks, quails, and other birds efficiently, ensuring healthy chicks. Farmers in Tamil Nadu use incubators for chicken, duck, kaadai (quail), and even turkey eggs when they want to hatch many eggs at once. Using an incubator is advantageous because it allows full control: maintain a steady temperature of 37.5 °C for chickens and 37.2 °C for ducks, keep moisture at 50–60%, and during the final three days in the hatcher, increase humidity to 65–75% for successful hatching. Eggs should be turned multiple times each day. In small manual incubators, eggs must be turned by hand, whereas in large automatic models, machines handle turning and maintain proper moisture automatically, resulting in higher hatch rates and uniform, healthy chicks. Incubators are available in two types: small manual incubators, which are affordable and suitable for backyard farmers, and large automatic incubators, which are more costly but ideal for commercial operations with less labor. Before placing eggs, always wash and disinfect the incubator with a safe disinfectant. During hatching, sprinkle a little clean water if needed to maintain moisture, and always monitor temperature. Candling should be done after seven days to check embryo growth. In Tamil Nadu, incubators are available in Coimbatore, Chennai, Namakkal, and through government supply chains. Local KVKs or TNAU extension offices can guide farmers to reliable dealers. With an incubator, there is no need to wait for a broody hen, and eggs can be hatched anytime and in bulk, ensuring a steady supply of chicks and consistent income.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of Rearing chicks?
Final Answer: Chicken rearing can provide a reliable income if proper steps are followed. Broilers like Cobb 500, Vencobb, and Ross 308 grow fast and reach approximately 2 kg in 6–7 weeks, while layers like White Leghorn and Rhode Island Red lay about 250–280 eggs per year. First, prepare a clean shed with good airflow and dry litter using materials such as rice husk or sawdust. Keep chicks warm at a temperature of 32–35 °C initially, gradually reducing it to 24 °C as they grow. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control chicken viral disease?
Final Answer: In poultry farming, the most dangerous trouble comes from viral diseases, and if TNAU advice is not followed properly, the whole flock can be lost in a few days. Among these, Ranikhet disease or Newcastle disease is the most feared because it spreads very fast through saliva, droppings, or water, and once it enters the shed, chicks start sneezing, gasping, drooping; some show green loose motion, some twist their necks, and finally, many die suddenly. In unvaccinated flocks, even 100% mortality can occur, causing farmers to lose birds, eggs, and income at once, and then face veterinary bills, disinfectant costs, government checks, and even market bans. Next, Infectious Bronchitis, which looks like a cold and cough in chickens, is very harmful as birds stop growing, lay poor-quality or misshapen eggs, and egg sales may fall. Marek’s disease attacks mainly young chicks, causing paralysis in legs and wings and even tumors inside the body; birds waste away, immunity drops, and farmers have to replace the flock and spend more money. Infectious Bursal Disease, or Gumboro, kills young chicks by causing white diarrhea, swollen bursa, and weak immunity; mortality can reach 80–90%, and even surviving birds never grow well, resulting in major profit loss and recurring disease costs. Avian Influenza, or Bird Flu, is extremely severe, with sudden deaths, bleeding, swelling in the face and comb; the whole farm can be sealed and culled by the government, and no sale is allowed, causing heavy financial and emotional loss. These viral diseases bring big losses—dead birds, poor growth, low eggs, extra medicine costs, and market restrictions—and neighboring farms may also be affected. The only way to prevent them is strict vaccination following the TNAU schedule and veterinary advice. Farmers should not wait when doubts arise; they must contact the Poultry Disease Diagnosis and Surveillance Laboratory (PDDSL) at Namakkal (phone 04286-266226, mail: adl-vcri@tanuvas.org.in, or check https://www.tanuvas.ac.in/lab_pddl.php for updated contact) or the TANUVAS Technology Centre at Madhavaram Milk Colony, Chennai. Sheds must be kept neat, visitors restricted, hands and feet washed before entry, and birds should receive probiotics, vitamins, and immunity boosters. Vaccination is the main defense since antibiotics cannot kill viruses. For example, Marek’s disease is vaccinated at 0 days, Ranikhet Lasota at 5–7 days, Infectious Bronchitis vaccine at 10th day, and IBD live vaccine at 12–14 days, followed by boosters as per the schedule. Secondary bacterial problems, if any, may be treated under veterinary supervision with antibiotics like Oxytetracycline or Enrofloxacin. Vaccines and support are available at Veterinary College Namakkal, Poultry Research Station Chennai, TANUVAS hospitals, and local KVKs. By following these steps, farmers can protect their flocks from viral diseases, ensure healthy growth, prevent mortality, and secure a steady income.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Why do Lac insects sometimes fail to produce sufficient resin?

Pest infestations pose another challenge, as beetles, moths, and parasitic wasps often prey on lac insects. Overcrowding of insects on branches leads to resource competition, etc. To improve lac production, you have to do proper host tree selection, like kusum and palash trees, which are considered ideal hosts for optimal resin yield. Regular pest control measures should be implemented, including neem oil (100 ml/acre) sprays or diluted malathion (0.05%, 200-250 ml/acre) applications with a 7-10 day interval period. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of making biodiesel?
Final Answer: Biodiesel is a renewable fuel made from natural sources such as vegetable oils, animal fats, or used cooking oil. The primary process used to produce biodiesel is called transesterification. In this process, the oil or fat is reacted with methanol in the presence of a catalyst, such as sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide. This chemical reaction breaks down the triglycerides in the oil into methyl esters (which are biodiesel) and glycerin (a by-product). After the reaction, the mixture is settled to separate the biodiesel and glycerin. The biodiesel is then washed with water to remove impurities and dried to eliminate moisture. Separated biodiesel is used in diesel engines either alone or blended with petroleum diesel, offering a cleaner and more sustainable alternative. Requires basic equipment such as a reactor tank for mixing, a separation tank, a washing unit, and a drying system. It’s important to follow proper safety precautions, as methanol is highly flammable and toxic, and the catalysts used are caustic.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are Biological units in Agriculture?
Final Answer: Biological units are the backbone of agriculture, which is defined as any living organism that plays a crucial role in farming systems, contributing to productivity, sustainability, and ecological balance. These units can include plants, animals, microorganisms, and even integrated systems like agroecosystems. There are several types of biological units in agriculture, like plants (crops), which are primary producers that convert sunlight into biomass through photosynthesis. For example, cereals (wheat, rice, and maize), legumes (soybeans and pulses), vegetables, fruits, and cash crops (cotton and sugarcane). This helps in food production and improves soil fertility. Legumes fix nitrogen. Animals (livestock) are the secondary producers that convert plant biomass into animal products, e.g., cattle, poultry, sheep, goats, pigs, and fish (in aquaculture). These provide meat, milk, eggs, wool, and leather. After that, microorganisms (soil & plant microbiome) play a role in decomposers & symbionts, which enhance nutrient cycling and plant health, e.g., bacteria (Rhizobium – nitrogen fixation, Pseudomonas – biocontrol). Fungi (mycorrhizae – nutrient uptake, Trichoderma – pathogen suppression). Also, pollinators & beneficial insects are there, which control pests as well as help in pollination. Agroecosystems (integrated biological units) are like farming systems combining crops, livestock, and trees. Biological units are mainly used in sustainable production, nutrient cycling, pest & disease management, and economic benefits. You have to do management of biological units by doing crop rotation, using integrated pest management (IPM), organic farming, etc. Future prospects of the biological unit are to use biofertilizers & biostimulants, and also to do precision agriculture farming, where genetic improvements are also an important part.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of making 1% Bordeaux mixture?

Use a plastic or wooden container (avoid metal) and stir until completely dissolved. Then, for the preparation of lime solution, take 4 kg of hydrated lime, mix with 50 litres of water in a separate container, and stir to form a smooth milky solution. After this, mix both solutions. Slowly pour the copper sulfate solution into the lime solution and stir continuously during mixing. While mixing, never reverse the mixing order (always copper to lime). The mixture should turn sky blue when it is properly neutralised, and finally, add the remaining 300 litres of water. After this, the total volume becomes 400 litres and is strained through cloth to remove particles. Don't store the mixture for more than 24 hours, and avoid spraying in direct sunlight. The best spraying time is early morning or late evening, when spray stems and pseudostems are completely dry. You can use it in a 7-10 day gap (infestation appearance). For safety measures, always wear gloves and eye protection. Before use, take a clean iron knife and dip it into the final solution; if a brownish deposit forms, more lime is needed to prevent leaf burn.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the process of making compost?
Final Answer: Composting is the natural process of decomposing organic materials such as crop residues, animal waste, and selected municipal and industrial wastes through the activity of microorganisms under controlled conditions. This process results in the formation of compost, a nutrient-rich substance that significantly enhances soil fertility and structure. Compost is broadly classified into types such as farm compost, derived from agricultural waste, and town compost, produced from urban refuse. These two vary in their nutrient content. The process of compost making is methodical and involves several stages. Typically, composting is carried out in pits of varying sizes, depending on the availability and volume of waste material. A layer of organic waste is first laid in the pit, moistened with 5–10 kg of cow dung in 2.5 to 5.0 litres of water, and uniformly sprinkled with 0.5–1.0 kg of fine bone meal. Subsequent layers are added in the same manner until the material reaches approximately 0.75 metres above ground level. The filled pit is then covered with wet mud and left for 8 to 10 weeks for well decomposition. Then, the plaster is removed, the material is moistened again, given a turning for aeration, and shaped into a rectangular heap under a shaded area, where it continues to decompose until ready for use. Compost improves the soil in multiple ways. Physically, it enhances aeration, water retention, and soil structure. Chemically, it enriches the soil with essential macro- and micronutrients. Biologically, it supports microbial activity, which is vital for nutrients and soil health.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Congress grass (Gajar ghas)?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the symptoms of copper deficiency in crops?
Final Answer: Copper deficiency is common in sandy or highly leached soil. To identify the copper deficiency, observe young and new leaves because it appears first in new leaves that turn pale or yellowish green; leaves look dull; leaf tips twist and whiten or dry from the top in cereal crops; your plants may produce fewer flowers and fruits; poor grain filling; and gummosis in fruit crops. To control copper deficiency in crops, give a foliar spray of copper sulfate (CuSO₄) at 2 g/liter to neutralize the solution. You can add an equal amount of lime to prevent the acidic copper sulfate from burning the tender leaves. Or give a soil application of copper sulfate at 5-10 kg/acre based on a soil test report, as excessive copper can become toxic to the soil and plants over time.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the symptoms of sulphur deficiency in crops?
Final Answer: Deficiency of sulphate (sulphur deficiency) in crops leads to the following symptoms: yellowing of young leaves first (unlike nitrogen deficiency, which affects older leaves) because sulphur is less mobile in plants; overall pale-green plants with reduced growth; thin, spindly stems; and delayed maturity. In cereals, deficiency causes reduced tillering and smaller heads. In oilseeds, it results in poor seed set and reduced oil content. In legumes, it causes reduced nodulation and poor nitrogen fixation. Deficiency is indicated if leaf sulphur content falls below 0.2% (varies with crop). Yield reduction can range from 10–30% in cereals and up to 40–50% in oilseeds. Oil content in mustard and sunflower may drop by 5–10%. The quality of onion and garlic also declines, with reduced pungency and storage life. To control sulphur deficiency: Soil application – Gypsum (18% S) @ 100–150 kg per acre; SSP (12% S) @ 150–200 kg per acre; Ammonium sulphate (24% S) @ 40–50 kg per acre; Elemental sulphur (85–100% S) @ 20–30 kg per acre for moderate needs, and 40–100 kg per acre for high-demand crops or alkaline soils. Foliar spray (curative measure) – For quick recovery in standing crops, spray a 0.5%–1% solution of a water-soluble sulphur fertilizer. This provides sulphur directly to the leaves for immediate uptake.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What causes dieback in orange trees, and how can I manage it effectively?

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How does excess water affect Tobacco cultivation?
Final Answer: Excess water in tobacco cultivation can cause significant damage to the plants. When soil becomes waterlogged, the roots suffer from oxygen deprivation, leading to root rot and decay. This condition also washes away essential nutrients like nitrogen, potassium, and calcium, resulting in deficiencies that weaken the plants. Stunted growth commonly occurs as the damaged roots cannot properly support plant development. The moist environment encourages fungal diseases such as black shank and bacterial wilt, which can destroy entire fields. Leaves may turn yellow due to poor nutrient absorption, and the overall leaf quality deteriorates, producing thin leaves, etc. To prevent water-related issues, proper field selection is important. Avoid low-lying areas with poor drainage and instead choose well-drained sandy loam soils with a pH between 5.8 and 6.5. Planting tobacco on raised beds about 15-20 cm. Maintaining spacing of 60-90 cm between rows and incorporating organic matter like compost or planting cover crops such as clover can enhance soil structure and water management without causing waterlogging. Also, you should install open ditches or subsurface tile drains to remove excess water efficiently. Applying fungicides like copper oxychloride 50% WP (3-4 gm/lit., 1 kg/acre) or metalaxyl 8% + mancozeb 64% WP @ 2.5 g/Lwith an 8-10 day interval period. Can control potential fungal outbreaks. Foliar sprays with balanced NPK fertilizers and micronutrients help compensate for nutrients lost through leaching.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the role and function of GA₃ (Gibberellic Acid) in crops?
Final Answer: Gibberellic Acid (GA3) is a naturally occurring plant hormone that acts as a powerful Plant Growth Regulator (PGR). It controls crucial developmental processes within the plant. In agriculture, it is used commercially as a product (usually a powder or liquid concentrate) to manipulate plant growth in a way that enhances yield and quality. Its primary role is to promote the elongation of cells, leading to longer stems and stalks. This is often seen as rapid vertical growth. It can break the natural resting state (dormancy) of seeds, buds, and tubers, leading to faster and more uniform sprouting. It can encourage flowering, especially in plants that require specific day lengths (long-day plants) or cold periods to flower. By stimulating cell division and elongation, it significantly helps in increasing the size and weight of the fruit. Helps in the transition of flowers into fruit, reducing flower and young fruit drop. In some crops, such as citrus, it can delay the ageing and yellowing of the rind, allowing the fruit to remain on the tree longer and thus extending the harvest period. When used correctly, GA3 provides several tangible benefits to farmers, such as increased yield, enhanced quality, and uniform germination. Dosage is extremely important, as too much GA3 can cause negative effects like weak, spindly growth. For crops like grapes, to increase bunch length and berry size at 25 - 50 PPM, apply at pre-bloom and post-fruit set stages. Cotton—To improve boll setting and retention at 20-30 PPM at the peak flowering stage. Tomato/Brinjal—To increase fruit set and size, at 10-25 PPM, spray at the full bloom stage. Paddy (Rice)—To promote early seedling growth, 10 - 20 ppm is used in nursery beds 15 days before transplanting. Sugarcane—To increase stalk length and yield, at 75-100 PPM, spray on the crop around 90-120 days after planting. Potato: To break seed tuber dormancy at 1-2 PPM, dip seed potatoes in the solution before planting for 15-20 minutes. Understanding Dosage in PPM (Parts Per Million): The concentration of GA3 is measured in PPM. This is a very small unit. 1 PPM = 1 milligram (mg) of GA3 dissolved in 1 liter of water. To make a 10 PPM solution: Dissolve 1 gram of GA3 in 100 litres of water (1000 mg / 100 L = 10 mg/L = 10 PPM). To make a 50 PPM solution: Dissolve 1 gram of GA3 in 20 litres of water (1000 mg / 20 L = 50 mg/L = 50 PPM). Spray during the cool hours of the day, either early in the morning or late in the evening, to prevent rapid evaporation and ensure maximum absorption by the leaves.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the important care and management practices for Hasta Bahar (Pomegranate off-season flowering)?

Regular irrigation every 10-15 days and mulching help retain moisture. For dieback, prune affected branches and spray either Mancozeb 75 WP (2.5 g/liter, waiting period: 7-10 days) or Propiconazole 25 EC (1 ml/4 litre, waiting period: 10–14 days). To reduce fruit drop, spray NAA (1 ml/litre, waiting period: 7 days) or 2,4-D (1 ml/litre, waiting period: 14 days) after fruit set. With proper irrigation, nutrition, and plant protection, Hasta Bahar results in high-quality fruits and better income for citrus growers.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are herbicides, and why are they used in crops?
Final Answer: Herbicides are chemical substances used to control or eliminate weeds that compete with crops for nutrients, water, sunlight, and space, which ultimately reduces yields. For example, in soybeans, a commonly used pre-emergent herbicide is Pendimethalin, applied at 1.0 to 1.5 litres per acre within 2 days of sowing. In sugarcane, Atrazine is often used as a pre-emergent at 1 to 1.2 kg per acre to control broadleaf weeds and grasses. For rice, Butachlor is used as a pre-emergent herbicide, while 2,4-D is effective as a post-emergent spray in dryland wheat fields. Herbicides can be selective (targeting specific weeds without harming the crop) or non-selective (killing all vegetation, best used before planting). They are also classified by timing: pre-emergent (before weed seeds germinate) and post-emergent (after weeds appear). Always follow recommended dosage, spray intervals, and safety guidelines to prevent crop injury and environmental harm. For best results, integrate herbicide use with manual weeding, mulching, and crop rotation; this is known as Integrated Weed Management (IWM), which ensures long-term weed control and sustainable farming.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the procedure for preparing vermicompost?
Final Answer: If you want to prepare vermicompost, here is a simple, step-by-step method you can follow: First, choose a place & bed size, such as picking a shaded, well-drained spot near water and building a raised bed about 10 ft × 3 ft × 2 ft (or a cement pit of similar volume). Then collect semi-decomposed cow dung, around 800-1,000 kg, plus chopped dry crop residue, about 300-400 kg (or kitchen waste mixed in a small quantity), and mix and keep this pile moist for 10-15 days so it partially decomposes and cools (this protects the worms). Then do bed layering: about 2-3 inches of sand/soil or broken bricks for drainage, then a 6-inch moist bedding of dry leaves/straw or coir, and add alternate layers of the pretreated cow dung and crop residue until the bed is filled, sprinkling water so the mix feels like a squeezed sponge (about 60-70% moisture). Then add worms such as Eisenia fetida (red wiggler) or Eudrilus eugeniae; for one standard bed (about 1-1.5 tonnes), introduce roughly 1 kg of earthworms per 100 kg of raw material (1–2 kg worms per bed). You can get them from your local KVKs. After that, cover the bed with a moist gunny bag or banana leaves and keep it in the shade (ideal temp 20-30°C), stir gently once or twice a week if needed, but avoid rough turning early on. Maintain steady moisture (sprinkle water every 2-3 days in hot weather), avoid direct sunlight, and avoid adding citrus, oily, or salty wastes. If the bed smells bad, it is too wet. Add dry leaves and turn. After 20–25 days, do a gentle mixing for aeration (careful not to hurt worms). Vermicompost will be ready in 45–60 days when it is dark brown, crumbly, and odourless. Stop watering 3-4 days before harvest so worms move down, then sieve or separate worms by light exposure. You can expect about 250-350 kg of finished vermicompost per tonne of raw material. Apply 2–3 tonnes/acre as a soil application or 10-15% in potting.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the possible soil improvement practices for muddy or waterlogged land?
Final Answer: Improving muddy or waterlogged land requires a step-by-step process to correct it. The first is to level the land properly to improve uniform water flow and avoid water stagnation. After levelling, install a drainage system to remove excess water from the field, which helps to stop root damage and fungal diseases. For small or medium farms, surface drains (shallow channels) or a raised bed and furrow system are cost-effective methods to allow excess water to flow out and keep root zones aerated. In areas with persistent waterlogging, constructing open ditches around field borders can also help. Next, soil amendments like gypsum can be added, especially in clayey/mud soils, to improve soil texture and make the soil more workable. Gypsum helps in breaking down hard clods, improving aeration, and promoting better root development. In addition to gypsum, farmers should mix in coarse organic materials like rice husk, coir pith, compost, or sand to further loosen the soil and improve water infiltration. Combining land levelling, subsurface drainage for high-value crops in heavy clay soils, gypsum application, and organic amendments leads to improvement in soil structure, better crop establishment, and higher productivity in problematic muddy fields.

You can visit or contact the Regional Sericulture Office, the Central Silk Board (CSB), State Sericulture Department; or the Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK), Aurangabad. Private Suppliers: You can also source DFLs from private sellers like Maa Bhagwati Silk and Aurangabad Seri-Culture, who also sell equipment and mulberry saplings. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Capsicum?
Final Answer: Capsicum can be grown in three main seasons with proper planning and care. For the kharif crop, nursery sowing is conducted from May 25 to June 10, with transplanting taking place between June 20 and July 5, and harvesting commencing from mid-August. The rabi crop is the most favourable for quality produce, with nursery sowing from 20 September to 10 October, transplanting from 15 October to 5 November, and harvesting beginning in late November or December. For the summer crop, which requires irrigation and protection from heat, nursery sowing is carried out from 20 January to 10 February, transplanting from 15 February to 5 March, and harvesting starting in late March or April; shade nets (35-50%) and drip irrigation are recommended to prevent flower drop and sunscald in the summer season. In open fields, a spacing of 45 cm between plants and 60 cm between rows is ideal, while in polyhouses, a spacing of 30-45 cm between plants and 60-75 cm between rows is preferred.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What care should I take while preparing a nursery bed for vegetable crops?
Final Answer: The major crops grown on raised seedlings in nursery beds are vegetables like tomato, brinjal, cucumber, chilli, cabbage, capsicum, papaya, citrus, and paddy, especially in regions with heavy black soils. Because it improves drainage, helps in root development, and is easy for drip irrigation. Prepare raised beds about 15-20 cm high to prevent waterlogging. Width: 1 m-1.22 m (for easy management); length: as per space. Treating raised beds before sowing is very important to ensure healthy soil, reduce pest and disease risks, and improve crop productivity. treat nursery beds, you can do first soil solarization 3-4 weeks before sowing and give organic treatment like FYM (2-3 tonnes/acre), vermicompost (4-5 tonnes/acre), and neem cake (200-300 kg/acre) at the time of land preparation. You can also use mulch to prevent weeds from retaining moisture and to reduce soil-borne diseases.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which papaya varieties are suitable for cultivation?
Final Answer: Farmers can grow both dioecious and gynodioecious papaya varieties depending on the market demand and climate. Popular choices include Red Lady (Taiwan 786), Pusa Nanha, Pusa Delicious, Pusa Dwarf, and Pusa Majesty. Among these, Red Lady is most preferred for its high yield (about 200-240 quintals per acre) and tolerance to Papaya Ring Spot Virus (PRSV) and some leaf curl issues. Pusa Nanha is a dwarf type, ideal for high-density planting and easier harvesting, with yields of around 150-180 quintals per acre. The seed rate for papaya is generally about 80-100 g per acre, sown in nursery beds or polybags before transplanting. Spacing varies by variety; for normal planting, 2 m × 2 m or 2.5 m × 2.5 m is common (about 800-1,100 plants/acre), while dwarf or high-density systems can use 1.8 m × 1.8 m spacing (about 1,200 plants/acre). Proper male-to-female plant ratios must be maintained in dioecious types for good fruit set, while gynodioecious varieties like Red Lady don’t require this. Choosing varieties with disease resistance, especially against PRSV, powdery mildew, and anthracnose, helps reduce pesticide costs and maintain fruit quality.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Telya (Oil Spot disease) in Dalimb (Pomegranate)?
Final Answer: In dalimb (pomegranate) cultivation, “Telya” is the farmer’s common name for oil spot disease, which is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. punicae. Symptoms of oil spot disease are small, dark brown to black spots that appear on leaves, fruits, and stems. Spots often have an oily or wet-looking margin (hence the name Telya, meaning oily). In fruits, these spots become sunken and hard, reducing market value. Severe infection causes leaf drop, fruit cracking, and yield loss. In Sangli, favourable conditions for this are hot and humid weather during monsoon and post-monsoon, dense canopy with poor air circulation, and overhead irrigation splashing water from infected to healthy plants. To manage this, you can prune and remove infected parts, burn or bury to stop spreading, improve air circulation by keeping the canopy open, and avoid water stagnation. Or give a preventive spray of copper oxychloride at 2.5-3 g per litre every 15-20 days (monsoon) and every 20-25 days (winter) during infection-prone season, or for large-scale spraying, use copper oxychloride at 1.5 kg/acre in 500 litres of water. Use resistant varieties that show less susceptibility (e.g., Bhagawa is moderately tolerant compared to Ganesh). Avoid overhead irrigation; use drip to reduce leaf wetness.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Anthracnose in Moong (Green gram)?
Final Answer: Anthracnose in mung (green gram) during the Rabi season is a serious fungal disease caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. It can spread quickly under cool, humid conditions and cause major yield losses if not identified and managed in time. Symptoms appear on leaves as small, dark brown to black spots with slightly sunken centres, often surrounded by a yellow halo. In severe cases, spots may merge, causing leaf blight; on stems & petioles, there are dark, elongated lesions that may girdle and weaken stems; on pods, sunken, dark brown to black spots are observed; seeds inside may be shrivelled or discoloured. This disease often spreads from infected seeds and plant debris, especially after rain or irrigation splashes. To control this, always use disease-free seed such as Pusa Vishal, Meha (MH-421), and IPM 2-14. 2. Treat seeds with Thiram 3 g/kg seed. Remove and burn infected plant residues after harvest to prevent carryover. Maintain proper spacing (30 × 10 cm) for better air circulation. At the first sign of disease, give a spray of Mancozeb at 2.5 g/liter water or Carbendazim at 1 g/liter water. Repeat after 10-15 days if needed, alternating chemicals to prevent resistance. Do not give spray 15 days before harvesting. Always wear goggles, gloves, a full-sleeve shirt, boots, and a mask while spraying chemicals.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Red Bittle in Pumpkin?
Final Answer: Pumpkin is a Kharif season crop. The term “red beetle” generally refers to two different pests depending on the crop and region, and both can cause significant losses if not managed in time. Red Pumpkin Beetle - symptoms: Adult beetles feed on leaves, flowers, and tender shoots, leaving irregular holes. They often attack seedlings, sometimes cutting them completely. Larvae feed on roots and underground stems, causing wilting. Infestation is most severe in seedlings to early vegetative stages, soon after germination, during monsoon humidity. Control measures are Cultural practices- perform deep summer ploughing and practice crop rotation, prefer early sowing (July–August) in the Kharif season. Mechanical control- Use yellow sticky traps or yellow basin traps with water and a few drops of kerosene to attract and kill beetles. Protect young seedlings with net covers or row covers for the first 2-3 weeks. Botanical - Apply Azadirachtin 1500 ppm @ 3 ml/L of water. Chemical control- Malathion 50% EC: 250 ml per acre; repeat every 5-7 days, Imidacloprid 17.8% SL: 50 ml per acre; repeat every 5-7 days. These sprays effectively reduce red pumpkin beetle populations and crop damage in cucurbits.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the harvesting period of Black Pepper?
Final Answer: You can harvest black pepper during the winter and early in the summer. Also, you should check the climatic conditions for cultivation practices. Black pepper vines usually begin flowering in May-June, and the berries take 6-8 months to mature. Farmers monitor the berries closely, as the ideal harvest time is when a few berries in a spike turn red or orange, indicating the onset of ripening. It gives a yield of up to 2-3 kg/plant (220-270 kg/acre).

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I manage fog problems on the crop?
Final Answer: Fog is a weather phenomenon where tiny water droplets remain suspended in the air near the ground, reducing visibility and increasing humidity. While fog can provide moisture to crops, prolonged foggy conditions can lead to several agricultural problems, including disease outbreaks, delayed growth, and reduced photosynthesis. Where fungal disease like powdery mildew, downy mildew, and blight are rapidly increasing their attack. Optimised irrigation to avoid overwatering; use drip irrigation instead of sprinklers. Install drainage systems to prevent waterlogging. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the procedure for preparing Vermicompost?
Final Answer: For vermicompost preparation, you have to first choose a place & bed size, such as pick a shaded, well-drained spot near water, build a raised bed about 10 ft x 3 ft x 2 ft (or a cement pit of similar volume). Then collect semi-decomposed cow dung around 800-1,000 kg plus chopped dry crop residue about 300-400 kg (or kitchen waste mixed in a small quantity), mix and keep this pile moist for 10-15 days so it partially decomposes and cools (this protects the worms). Then do Bed layering about 2-3 inches of sand/soil or broken bricks for drainage, then a 6-inch moist bedding of dry leaves/straw or coir, add alternate layers of the pretreated cow dung + crop residue until bed is filled, sprinkling water so the mix feels like a squeezed sponge (about 60-70% moisture). Then add worms such as Eisenia fetida (red wiggler) or Eudrilus eugeniae, for one standard bed (about 1-1.5 tonnes), introduce roughly 1 kg of earthworms per tonne of raw material (1-2 kg worms per bed). You can get them from your local KVKs. After that, cover the bed with a moist gunny bag or banana leaves and keep in shade (ideal temp 20-30°C), stir gently once or twice a week if needed, but avoid rough turning early on. Maintain moisture steady (sprinkle water every 2-3 days in hot weather), avoid direct sunlight, and avoid adding citrus, oily, or salty wastes. If the bed smells bad, it is too wet. Add dry leaves and turn. After 20-25 days, do a gentle mixing for aeration (careful not to hurt worms). Vermicompost will be ready in 45-60 days when it is dark brown, crumbly, and odourless. Stop watering 3-4 days before harvest so worms move down, then sieve or separate worms by light exposure. You can expect about 300-400 kg of finished vermicompost per tonne of raw material. Apply 2-3 tonnes/acre as a soil application or 10-15% in potting.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which are the suitable varieties of amaranthus?
Final Answer: Amaranthus is grown throughout the year, but it is mainly a summer crop. Amaranthus is a highly nutritious crop grown for both its grains and leaves. QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I make the dashparni arka?
Final Answer: Dashparni Ark is prepared using a traditional fermentation method. The process involves ten main ingredients: fresh leaves of neem (500g), tulsi (500g), bel (300g), gular (300g), ashoka (300g), arjuna (300g), kanchan (200g), shatavari (200g), daruharidra (200g), and patola (200g). Finely chop all the leaves and mix them in a clay pot with 8-10 litres of cow urine and 2 litres of cow dung slurry. Cover it with a cotton cloth and let it ferment for 30-40 days, stirring it every day for proper breakdown of the organic matter. After fermentation, filter the liquid through a muslin cloth. For spraying, prepare 5 litres of Dashparni Ark for every 100 litres of water (80-100 litres per acre are required). You can use it to control pests like aphids, mites, and caterpillars, while also preventing fungal and bacterial infections such as powdery mildew and leaf spot. It also acts as a growth stimulant and increases soil health.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which season/month is suitable for pruning in Grape cultivation?
Final Answer: Grape pruning is best done twice a year. First, back pruning is typically done in March–April after the harvest, and second, forward pruning is done in September–October to induce the main fruiting season (before flowering, depending on the variety). Farmers grow popular varieties like Thompson Seedless (a seedless variety with a pleasant, sweet taste), Sonaka (very long and elongated, which gives them a distinctive look and good market price), and Manik Chaman (elongated and seedless, similar to Sonaka, but they have a slightly different flavour and high yield potential). Pruning should remove old, diseased, and weak canes, keeping only 8–10 healthy buds per cane for a better fruit set. Before pruning, you can apply 1% Bordeaux mixture (2 kg copper sulphate and 2 kg lime in 200 litres of water per acre) or, as an alternative, Copper Oxychloride 50% WP at 500 g per acre in 200 litres of water to prevent fungal infection. Make sure the water volume ensures full coverage of the vines. After pruning, apply 4–5 tons of FYM + 50 kg of SSP + 25 kg of MOP per acre as a basal dose immediately after forward pruning (in September-October) to support the new growth and fruiting cycle and irrigate lightly. Always disinfect pruning tools with a 0.5% Bleaching powder solution to avoid disease spread. Timely, clean pruning helps in uniform bud sprouting, better bunch quality, and higher market returns. Avoid heavy irrigation immediately after pruning to prevent shoot rot. Rotate pruning times slightly each year to balance plant vigour and yield.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the application rate of anti-transparent Kaolin?
Final Answer: For using anti-transparent kaolin clay, you can mix a 2-5% concentration (20-50 gm of kaolin per litre of water or 3-6 kg per acre in 200 liters of water). On fruit crops (apples, grapes), you can use 3-4 sprays per season at a 5% concentration. On vegetables (tomatoes, peppers), you should use 2-3 sprays at a 4% concentration. You can apply it every 7-10 days during pest/disease appearance. You can also mix it with compatible fungicides/insecticides. Try to avoid mixing it with sulfur-based products, as it may reduce efficacy. It is non-toxic to humans, bees, and beneficial insects. Avoid over-application, as it may reduce the photosynthesis process.
